editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Man's bewitch'd; OR, The Devil to do about Her. A COMEDY, As it is Acted at the NEW-THEATRE IN THE HAY-MARKET; BY HER MAJESTY's SERVANTS.
LONDON, Printed for BERNARD LINTOTT, between the Two Temple-Gates in Fleet-ſtreet.

div.head: To His GRACE WILLIAM Duke of Devonſhire; Lord Steward of Her Majeſty's Houſhold, Lord in Eyre, North of Trent, Lord Lieutenant of the County of Derby; and One of Her Majeſty's Moſt Honourable Privy Council, &c.
div.p:
THE Muſes were ever ambitious of being diſtinguiſh'd, by ſhrouding themſelves under the Patronage of the greateſt Men in all Ages; not made ſo by Titles or Preferment; but ſuch, whoſe innate Principles of Honour, truly ſupported thoſe their Prince had crown'd them with. From hence ſprung my Preſumption of laying the following Scenes at Your Grace's Feet; ſince the World muſt allow, that all thoſe Virtues, which compleat a perfect good, as well as great Man, are
center'd in the Duke of Devonſhire; the loyaleſt Subject, the tendereſt Huſband, and the kindeſt Maſter, that ever Monarch, Wife, or Servant had; Briliant Graces, but ſuch as do not ſhine in every Man of Quality. From ſuch Patriots, what may not Britain hope? Nay, what might not She command, were all her Sons as fervent for her Intereſt, and diſcharg'd their reſpective Truſts with that Fidelity, and due Regard to the publick Good, as Your Grace has ever done in Yours: Then the hated Name of Faction wou'd be heard no more, and the ſcandalous Wounds of hot-headed Parties heal'd; which is the only way to ſecure this Iſland from foreign Inſults, and eſtabliſh Peace more firmly, than Armies, tho' vaſt as Xerxes led, can do.

To attempt your Grace's Character, is the ſuperiour buſineſs of a Maſculine Pen, and not to be reach'd by mine: But ſince my Huſband has the Honour to ſerve Her Majeſty, under the Command of Your Grace, as he did the late King of glorious Memory, under that of your noble Father, I cou'd not be prevail'd upon to alter my
Reſolution of prefixing your Grace's Name in the front of this Poem, at once to ſhew my Gratitude, and my Ambition: And if, when Your Grace's Mind's unbended from the Care and Buſineſs of the State, it finds the way in ſome leiſure Hour to divert Your Grace, and the Author meet your Pardon for this Liberty, my Wiſhes are all anſwer'd; as I hope my Prayers will be, that Your Grace may enjoy a perfect Health, free from Pain in Mind, and Body; and ſee as many flouriſhing happy New Years, as your beſt and deareſt Friends can deſire; and every one add freſh Honours to thoſe that are ſo deſervedly worn by Your Grace at preſent, which are the earneſt Wiſhes of

closer.signed: Your Grace's Moſt Obedient, and Moſt Devoted, Humble Servant, SUSANNA CENT-LIVRE.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
I Shou'd not have troubled my Courteous Reader with a Preface, had I not lain under the Neceſſity of Clearing my ſelf of what ſome People have been pleas'd to charge me with, viz. of being the Author of a Paper call'd, The Female Tattler, conſequently of a Paragraph in that of the 14th Inſtant, relating to this Comedy; tho' I think no reaſonable Perſon will believe I could be guilty of ſo much Folly. Tho' Vanity is ſaid to be the darling Vice of Womankind, yet nothing but an Idiot wou'd expreſs themſelves ſo openly; and I hope the World won't think me guilty of Printing, what I muſt bluſh to Read, nor imagine it Wrote even by any Friend of mine, for two Reaſons; Firſt, the Groſſneſs of the Flattery. Secondly, the Injury it muſt of courſe do me, in the Run of my Play, by putting thoſe People out of Humour, whoſe Action was to give Life to the Piece. I ſuppoſe theſe Reaſons are ſufficient to convince the Judicious part, that I was no ways concerned in thoſe Reflections, but own I was treated with all the ſeeming Civility in the World, till the ſecond Night of my Comedy. I willingly ſubmitted to Mr. Cibber's Superiour Judgment in ſhortning the Scene of the Ghoſt in the laſt Act, and believed him perfectly in the Right, becauſe too
much Repetition is tireſome. Indeed when Mr. Eſtcourt ſlic'd moſt of it out, I cou'd not help interpoſing my Deſires to the contrary, which the reſt readily comply'd with; and I had the Satisfaction to ſee I was not deceiv'd in my Opinion, of its pleaſing. This Paſſage I happen'd to mention among my Acquaintance; for 'tis Natural to have a kind of a Tender for our own Productions, but eſpecially if they have the good Fortune to divert others. Now, if from this the Author of the Tattler gather'd his Account, I am guilty of ſpeaking, but not deſignedly; for who they are that Write that Paper, or how Diſtinguiſh'd, I am perfectly ignorant, and declare I never was concern'd, either in Writing, or Publiſhing, any of the Tattlers.

I never had the Vanity to think, much leſs to publiſh, that any thing I am capable of doing, cou'd ſupport the Stage, tho' I have had the good Fortune to pleaſe, or to find the Town willing to be pleas'd; tho' at preſent it ſeems a certain Author has enter'd a Caveat againſt all Plays running to a ſixth Night, but his own. Tho' an Opera interfer'd with this Comedy, yet it brought above Forty Pounds the ſecond Night, which ſhew'd it had ſome Merit; for I have known many a Play kept up, that fail'd of half that Money the ſecond Night. Now by the Rules of the Houſe, it ought to have been play'd on: But who can ſecure the Life of a Play, when that of a Man is often Sacrific'd to the Malice of Parties? This Play met with a kind Reception in general, and notwithſtanding the Diſadvantages it had to ſtruggle with, by raiſing the Prices the firſt Day, and the Nearneſs of Chriſtmas, it would have made its way to a ſixth Night, if it had had fair Play. Miſtake
me not, I do not mean from the Repreſentation; for I muſt do the Players Reaſon: Had I ſearch'd all the Theatres in the World, I cou'd not have ſelected a better Company, nor had more Juſtice done me in the Action, tho' they have not dealt honourably by me in my Bargain; for they ought not to have ſtop'd the Run, upon any Pique whatever. 'Tis ſmall Encouragment to Write for the Stage, when the Actors, according to the Caprice of their Humours, mangre the Taſte of the Town, have power to ſink the Reputation of a Play; for if they reſolve not to Act it, the Town can't ſupport it.

Well, if there is any Merit in ſuffering wrongfully, I ſhall find my Account in't one time or other; in the mean while I intreat the Female Tattler to be Witty no more at my Expence. I deſire I may not be rank'd in the Number of thoſe that ſupport the Stage, ſince the Stage is become a Noun Subſtantive, and reſolves to ſhew it is able to ſtand by itſelf.

div.head: PROLOGUE. By a GENTLEMAN. Spoken by Mr. WILKS.
div.l: OUR Female Author trembling ſtands within,
Her Fear ariſes from another's Sin;
One of her Sex has ſo abus'd the Town,
That on her Score ſhe dreads your angry Frown:
Tho' I dare ſay, poor Soul, ſhe never writ
Lampoon, or Satyr on the Box or Pit;
A harmleſs hum'rous Play is her Extent of Wit.
Tho' Bickerſtaff's vaſt Genius may engage,
And laſh the Vice and Follies of the Age;
Why ſhou'd tender Delia tax the Nation?
Stickle, and make a Noiſe for Reformation,
Who always gave a Looſe, her ſelf, to Inclination.
Scandal and Satyr's thrown aſide to Day,
And Humour the ſole Buſineſs of our Play.
Beaux may dreſs on to catch the Ladies Hearts,
And good Aſſurance paſs for mighty Parts:
The Citts may bring their Spouſes without Fear,
We ſhew no Wife that's poaching for an Heir,
Nor teach the Uſe of fine Gauſe Handkercheir.
Cowards may huff, and talk of mighty Wonders,
And Jilts ſet up—for Twenty thouſand Pounders.
Our Author, even tho' ſhe knows full well,
Is ſo Good-natur'd, ſhe forbears to tell
What Collonels, lately, have found out the Knack
To Muſter Madam, ſtill, by Ned, or Jack,
To keep their Pleaſures up; a Frugal way,
They give her—Subaltern's Subſiſtance for her Pay.
In ſhort, what e'er your Darling Vices are,
They paſs untouch'd in this Night's Bill of Fare.
But if all this can't your good Nature wake,
Tho' here and there, a Scene ſhou'd fail to take,
Yet ſpare her for the Buſie-Body's ſake.

div.head: EPILOGUE. Spoken by Mrs. OLDFIELD. Written by Mr. Cibber. A Porter delivers a Letter juſt as ſhe is going to ſpeak.
div.l: WHAT's this? a Billet-Deaux? from Hands unknown?
'Tis new to ſend it thus 'fore all the Town:
But ſince the poor Man's Paſſion's ſo agog,
I'll read it out by way of Epilogue.

body.l: Permit a Wretch to let you know,
That he's no more in Statu Quo.
My Ruine from this Night commences,
Unleſs your Smiles refund my Senſes;
For with one Thruſt of Cupid's Dart,
You've whip'd your Slave quite thro' the Heart:
Therefore, I beg you, caſt your Eye
In Pity of my Pains and Doubt,
And try if you can find me out.

div.l: Poor Soul! He ſeems indeed in diſmal Plight;
Let's ſee! it can't be, ſure! from th' upper Flight;
No, no—that's plain—for —None of them can Write:
Nor can I think it from the Middle fell;
For I'm afraid—as few of them can Spell:
Beſide, their Haggling Paſſions never gain,
Beyond the Paſſage-walking Nymphs of Drury-Lane:
And then the Pit's more ſtock'd with Rakes and Rovers,
Than any of theſe ſenſeleſs, whining Lovers.
The Backs o' th' Boxes too ſeem moſtly lin'd
With Souls, whoſe Paſſion's to themſelves confin'd.
I • ſ • ort, I can't perceive, 'mongſt all you Sparks,
The Wretch diſtinguiſh'd, by theſe bloody Marks.
But ſince the Town has heard your kind Commands, Sir,
The Town ſhall e'en be Witneſs of my Anſwer.
Firſt then, Beware you prove no Spark in Red,
With empty Purſe, and Regimental Head;
That thinks no Woman can refuſe t'engage in't,
While Love's advanc'd with offer'd Bills on Agent;
That ſwears he'll ſettle from his Joy's commencing,
And make the Babe, the Day he's Born, an Enſign.
Nor cou'd I bear a Titl'd Beau, that ſteals
From fasting Spouſe her Matrimonial Meals;
That Modiſh ſends next Morn to her Apartment,
A Civil How-deye—far alas! from th' Heart meant:
Then Powder'd for th' enſuing Day's Delights,
Bows thro' his Croud of Duns, and drives to White's.
Nor cou'd I like the Wretch, that all Night plays,
And only takes his Reſt on Winning Days;
That ſets up from a lucky Hit, his Rattler
Then's trac'd from his Orig'nal—in the Tattler.
To tell you all that are my fixt Averſion,
Wou'd tire the Tongue of Malice, or Aſperſion.
But if I find 'mongſt All One generous Heart,
That Deaf to Stories takes this Stage's Part;
That thinks that Purſe deſerves to keep the Plays,
Whoſe Fortune's bound for the Support of Opera's;
That thinks our Conſtitution here is juſtly fixt,
And now no more with Lawyers Brawls perplext.
He, I declare, ſhall my whole Heart receive;
And (what's more ſtrange) I'll love him while I live.

div.p: SCENE, the Minſter-yard in Peterborough. The Hour Six in the Morning.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE I. The Minſter-yard in Peterborough.
div.stage: Enter Captain Conſtant and Clinch in Mourning, with Riding Habit over it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: CLinch! Where are you Sirrah? Why don't you come along?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah! Pox of this riding Poſt,—Look ye, Captain; if you have threeſcore Miles farther to go, I am your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, I am at my Journey's end—This Town of Peterborough is the bound of all my Wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir! Pray be pleas'd to make it mine too.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why! what is your wiſh?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Why, with ſubmiſſion, Sir, to know the reaſon of your Expedition, and gravity of Habit: Have you a mind to ſet up the Buſineſs of an Undertaker here in the Country?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: No, Clinch, my buſineſs is with the Living, not with the Dead, I'll aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Then can't I for my blood imagine why you are thus dreſs'd; your Father, nay your whole Family are well; not ſo much as a Nephew, or ſecond Couſin dead; nay, nor no fear of Peace.——Then why the Devil are we in black? You laugh—Can theſe Cloaths cauſe Joy, without the Perquiſite that belongs to it: 'Tis a mournful Equipage, and ſhocks my Soul, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Perquiſite! Why what Perquiſite does Mourning bring with it to cauſe Joy? ha!

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir, ſeveral—As when a Wife buries her Huſband, ſhe has Sorrow in one hand, and Joy in t'other; a ſhort Widowhood cures ſuch a Grief—Or a rich Heir at the laſt Gaſp of his Parent, when there is a Years Rent in the Steward's
hands —But, Sir, to the point; either let me into the Secret, or diſcharge me.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; Why then if I muſt tell thee; this Habit, if Fortune favours me, will be worth to me two thouſand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir; and pray how much will it be worth to me? For I am dreſs'd like you—If I have not the ſame Privileges, why ſhould I be confin'd to the ſame Garb?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Oh! you ſhall have your part, Clinch, never fear.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, but there are ſome parts I don't care for—— I hope you have no deſign to rob upon the Highway.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, ben't angry Sir; if there ſhou'd be Peace, 'tis what many an honeſt Gentleman muſt come to. I have no averſion for the Name; but I have for the Puniſhment— I'll not ſtrike a ſtroke—therefore what good can I do you?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I ſhall have more occaſion for your Eyes, than your Arm—You can weep, Sirrah, can't you?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, I ſhall weep, that's certain, to ſee you come to the Gallows—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ye Dog you, I tell you there is no danger.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: No danger—Why then I ſhall weep for Joy, Sir— —but how, Sir, how; muſt I roar, or ſhed Tears?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: So you do but counterfeit well, no matter which.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah, let me alone for counterfeiting, I defie a Woman to out-do me in that—Look ye Sir, you ſhall hear — —hem, hem. Roars out.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Very well—be ſure when I weep—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I'll make terrible Faces—What think you; Sir, Is not my Pipe very muſical for weeping?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Oh! Excellent.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: But what does this ſignifie! Where lies the Myſtery?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p:
Well then—Since you muſt know it; You are not inſenſible how my Father has treated me, ever ſince I refus'd to marry Mrs. Homebred, whoſe Manners ſuited with her Name, and her Face was courſer than either; and becauſe I drew a Bill upon him for fifty Pounds laſt Campaign, he threatens to diſinherit me; nay, and ſwears, that if for the future I don't make it appear I live upon half my Pay, He'll
make my Serjeant his Heir, who was once his Footman. In ſhort, I can bear his ill uſage no longer.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, had you married that Lady with twenty thouſand Pounds, you need not have drawn upon him for fifty.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: If ſhe had twenty times as much, I ſhou'd refuſe her for Belinda's ſake.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: But Sir Jeffrey reſolves againſt that Match—You muſt not marry his Steward's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I hope to prove you a Lyar, Sir; and by this Dreſs to carry my deſign; which is to perſuade Truſty, that my Father dyed of an Apoplexy, by which means he muſt account with me for the half Years Rent, he ſent the old Gentleman word was ready for him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Two thouſand Pound, Clinch—This Letter I ſurpriz'd by an Accident; 'tis from my Father to him. Reads.

body.p: The ſeveral Sums which you have return'd me without any Receipt, amounts to eight hundred Pounds, there remains behind two thouſand two hundred Pounds, which you tell me is ready for me; don't give your ſelf any trouble about remitting that, for I deſign to be down my ſelf in a Fortnight; and then the Leaſes which you mention'd, ſhall be renew'd. You need write no more, till you ſee

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Excellent, Sir! Why here may be a pretty Penny towards, if the Devil don't croſs it. But, Sir, if my old Maſter ſhou'd take a Maggot, and write to Truſty, to return his Money after all—His Letter and our Story wou'd have ſmall connexion; we ſhou'd be oblig'd to alter our Note. I wou'd adviſe you to take the old Steward to the Tavern, and ſtay as little in his Houſe as you can, for fear of diſcovery: Beſides, Sir, a Glaſs of Wine and a Fowl, makes buſineſs go on chearfully, Sir.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Chearfully, Sirrah!—You don't conſider that it is not my buſineſs to be chearful—I admire Faithful ſtays ſo long.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Perhaps he can't find Mr. Lovely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I directed him to the Coffee-houſe, where he ſeldom fails to be at this time of the Morning.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman! I warrant he's ruminating upon his Misfortunes. Well! 'tis ſometimes a Bleſſing to want Money— —You 'ſcap'd the Highway-men, Sir!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What am I the better for that, Sirrah? My Pockets are as empty as my Friends, who fell into their Hands: But here comes my Fellow Traveller—and Lovely with him; He has found him at laſt— Dear Lovely, how is't?

div.stage: Enter Lovely, Faithful, and Manage, in Riding habit.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Captain Conſtant! Welcome! Who expected to ſee you here? Why did •• t you ſend me word of your coming?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: He hardly knew it himſelf two hours before he got on Horſeback, Sir; nay, I much queſtion if he knows it yet.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: My Journey indeed was ſomething Precipitate.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, don't you ſee we are in Mourning?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mr. Faithful has inform'd me of every Particular; and I wiſh I cou'd really give thee Joy of ſix thouſand a Year, Boy.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: At the rate of half a Years Rent you may—If Fortune proves not an errand Jilt indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen; What think you of my Houſe? I'll get ſomething for Breakfaſt, whilſt you change your Linen.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: 'Tis near Six—I have a mind to ſee if Belinda comes to Church this Morning.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: She ſeldom fails—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Prithee, Lovely; Can you inform me, if a young Lady that lives at Sir David Watchum's will be here too?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mrs. Laura Wealthy, Your Miſtreſs you mean.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: We have heard of the Lady; but I believe no body in Peterborough has ſeen her, except his own Servants.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What kind of a temper is the old Fellow of?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
The moſt peeviſh, ſplenetick, miſtruſtful, ill-natur'd Wretch in the whole County: He comes to the Coffee-houſe every Morning in an old ruſty Chariot for haſte, the longeſt Journey
he takes in the Year: He ſeldom comes to Church; nay, ſince that Lady came he has not once been ſeen there; we fancy he dares not ſtay two hours from home, for fear ſhe ſhould be ſtol'n away.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, this account is moſt uncomfortable in our Affairs—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: It gives me more Chagrin, than the Rogues did, when they ſtripp'd me of my Money this Morning— Which way ſhall I give Laura notice of my being in Town?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Have Courage, Faithful, I warrant we proſper.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nothing like a good Heart; you ſhall not want a ſmall Sum of Money, Sir.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I'll be as diligent in thy Affairs, as in my own— if any lucky Opportunity offers, I'll be ready to ſerve thee.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'll be the ſame to both.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I know it; and when I am able; as I hope if my deſign ſucceeds, thou ſhal't meet returns in me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to both—But who have we here?

div.stage: Several People croſs the Stage to Church.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Here comes Belinda, and with her my Tyrant Maria.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen; you'll beſt entertain your Miſtreſſes alone; I'll back to the Coffee-houſe, and over a Diſh of Tea think what Courſe to ſteer—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Mind if the Courant be there, wherein I got my Father's Death inſerted, the better to favour my Plot.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I will, Captain, and be ſure to confirm the News.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: We'll call of you there preſently—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: But is Maria obdurate ſtill Lovely?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not in reality, Conſtant—But ſhe has ſo much of the Woman in her, to keep up her Rule till the laſt.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ladies, good morrow! The ſound of the Saint's Bell brings Angels abroad. Salutes 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Conſtant! and in Mourning! Pray who's dead?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: One for whom I ought to grieve, did it not ſmooth a Paſſage to Belinda's Arms, through the Hearts of our inexorable Parents.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Father! Sir.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: The ſame, Madam! He's as dead as an Herring, I promiſe you—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now don't I know, whether I had beſt ſay I'm ſorry for your Loſs, or wiſh you much Joy of your Gain.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I dare ſwear, Madam, he can't tell you yet.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Peace, Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mr. Lovely, are you for Prayers?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: You are the Shrine he kneels to, Madam; if you'll vouchſafe to hear him, he can pray moſt devoutly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And diſſemble moſt fervently—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No faith, Madam, that Quality does not belong to us—that is the Womens Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And do you never encroach upon our Privileges, ſweet Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, yes faith; I have encroach'd upon ſome of the Sexes Privileges in my time, I muſt own. Curioſity— Madam, ſeldom leads us to put on Maſking Habits; but a Lady cannot dreſs without 'em; Diſſimulation is as neceſſary as her Patches.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay! How do you prove that?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why thus: When you wou'd gain a Man you like, you appear what you are not—We believe you Angels, but don't always find you ſo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We always find you Angels, but of the fal'n kind.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible to be otherwiſe, whilſt Beauty keeps her Court below, you charm our Eyes, and all our Senſes wait you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pride and Vanity predominate in your Sex, and like Centinels relieve one another; Pride has made a Lady ſwear ſhe has Hated ſuch a Man, tho' ſhe was dying for the Sight of him—And Vanity made her Careſs a Fop, that at the ſame time ſhe wiſh'd at the Devil.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
And are not you even with us? Will not you ſigh, ogle, cringe, flatter, ſwear, kneel, nay give it under your hand, you Love to deſperation; but let the poor miſtaken
Nymph once yield, and you'd give Bond and Judgment to that Old Gentleman you nam'd but now, in two Days to take her off your hands.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I hope you don't include the whole Sex, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That ſhe do's not, I'm ſure; for ſhe knows I never ſwore any thing to her, but what I am ready to make good— And if ſhe be not the moſt unconſcionable Woman living, ſhe will own I love her heartily.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: That I dare witneſs for thee, Lovely.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay! Why, what Proofs has he given?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Proofs! Why I talk of her all Day—And dream, of her all Night——When ſhe's abſent, ſigh for her, and am tranſported when I ſee her. If theſe be not proofs of Love, let the Parſon ſay Grace and I'll give her better.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: All this may be done without one Grain of Love, may it not Captain?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Not when you are the Object, Madam; and you are too well acquainted with my Heart, to aſk that Queſtion out of ſcruple, I'm certain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Theſe are no Proofs; you muſt grow Lean and Meagre—Eat little, and Sleep leſs—Write fifty Letters in a Day, and burn them all again—Then ſtart up, and draw your Sword; hold it to your Breaſt; then throw it away agen — Then take your Pen and write your laſt Farewel—Diſpatch it to your Miſtreſs—Then take a Turn by ſome melancholy purling Stream, with Hat pull'd o'er your Eyes, in deep Contemplation reſolve thro' what Door to let in Death, if the Meſſenger return without Succeſs—When I ſee you do this, I'll write Lover upon your Brow.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: When I do, you ſhall write Fool upon my Forehead.
sp.l: Hang this whining way of Wooing,
Loving was deſign'd a Sport, &c. Sings.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Come, come Madam, a Truce; you know he loves you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: As well as I know ſhe loves me; we were born for one another, Child; no Man in the Kingdom ſhall have thee, but my ſelf.—Then if you will eat Chalk, and die of the Pip, I can't help it. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Be not ſo poſitive Lovely.—One Sect of Philoſophers tells you, you ought to doubt of every thing.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But the Topick was not a Woman in that Aſſertion; but if it were, Women in their Days were no more like Women in ours, than a Clodhopper is to a Captain o' Foot. Our Ladies are like two Negatives, to be underſtood in the Affimative, ha, ha. Madam, do's not my Friend here look like one of thoſe Lovers you deſcrib'd? Faith, I think a Woman cannot wiſh a ſimpler Figure—Now has he a thouſand Things to ſay to Belinda alone.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: You gueſs right, Lovely—I am going to your Father's, Madam, to ſettle our Accounts; I hope you'll return as ſoon as Prayers are over.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Directly—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh Belinda!
Now is the Criſis of our Good or Ill;
Turn for me, Fate, or let thy Wheel ſtand ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You'll remember us in your Prayers, Ladies——

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Amongſt Jews, Turks and Infidels— Exit.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come, now for my Houſe—We'll call on Faithful.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Lead on—I'll change my Linen and to Truſty's immediately—But hold—Clinch, heark yee.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I had no Opportunity to inform Belinda of my Project; you muſt away to Truſty's and let her Maid into the Secret, I wou'd not impoſe upon her—The Man that truly Loves, cannot deceive the Object of his Vows.
sp.l: He never felt the Force of Cupid's Dart,
Who lets his Tongue run counter to his Heart;
Or ever can deſerve the Charming Maid,
That is by Falſhood to his Arms betray'd.
For mutual Paſſions in all States agree,
And lines the Yoke with true Felicity.
She ſhall my Project with my Love compare.
If ſhe approves it, I'm indeed an Heir.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Or at the worſt, we are but as we were.

div.stage: Enter 'Squire Num, and his Man Slouch.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p:
What think you Slouch! Had we beſt go into the Minſter, or tarry here whilſt Mrs. Belinda comes out; for her Maid ſays ſhe's here: Lord, Lord, how Religious Folk
are in this Town! Why they riſe as early to Church here, as our Parſon's Wife does to Milking, I think—Well, but what had we beſt to do, ha?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Why go in, I think—Or tarry here; which you will, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Nay, nay mun, I don't know which is beſt, that makes me ask you; for I know, Slouch, you underſtand Breeding and Haviours; for you have been at London with fat Bullocks, and ſo was never I; but I reſolve to go next time, ha! Slouch!

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Ay Maſter; but an you Marry this ſame Mrs. Belinda, as ſure as your Name is 'Squire Num, ſhe'll not let you budge a Step.

sp.speaker: Num,
sp.p: Marry her! Nay, nay, I ſhall Marry her, that's ſure enough, I think; and yet I'll ſee London for all that— Why, what doſt thou think I'll be ty'd to a Wife's Tail all Days o' my Life? No, no; the Family of the Nums won't be Wife-rid, Slouch—But heark yee, an her Father ſhou'd chop up the Wedding to Day, before my New Cloathes are made; for he likes me woundily mun.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Od well thought on Maſter! don't go into the Church, I ſay; who knows but when the Parſon has done his Prayers, but he may begin your Plagues, Maſter ha!

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Od that's ſmart now—Ha, ha, huſh, huſh, Slouch, they are here—Now ſhow your Manners—

div.stage: Enter Truſty, Belinda and Maria. Several others croſs the Stage as from Church.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I have met a Report in the Church, that the News ſays Sir Jeffry Conſtant is Dead; if it be true, there's a better Husband for Belinda than this Fool—Od! I'll for London as ſoon as I have Din'd; my Heart akes; pray Heaven he ſettled his Affairs before he died: I have no Receipt for the Money I paid him.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p:
Sir, your Servant; Father has ſent me agen to ſee Mrs. Belinda, and bid me tell you, That he wou'd come over himſelf, I think, next Week, an do what you wou'd have him do, I think—And ſo, I ſuppoſe, we are agreed, forſooth ——Only I muſt deſire you to ſtay till my New Cloathes
are made. Father bought the Cloth laſt Sturbich Fair; and the Taylor comes to Morrow, don't he Slouch?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Ay, and his Man Staytape too; an he works like a Dragon—My Maſter will ſoon be fit, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fit quotha! for what? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: For what! nay, nay, let me alone for that, an I don't ſhow her for what, when I have her once, I'll be flea'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Heaven defend me from the Tryal.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir, ſince I ſaw you laſt, I have conſider'd my Daughter is no proper Match for you; and therefore I deſire you to return with all poſſible Speed, and acquaint your Father, that he may not undertake an unneceſſary Journey.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ten thouſand Bleſſings on that Voice.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: High day: What's the matter now! Why you don't pretend to make a Fool of me, do ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, thou art made to his hands—ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Who ſpeaks to you Miſtreſs, I was not made for you I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, I thank my Stars!

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: I'll not be chous'd at this rate, mun: Did you not tell me, if my Father wou'd ſettle ſo, and ſo, that I ſhou'd have her—And now you come with a Conſider— when it has coſt me the Lord knows what in Journeys, as Slouch can teſtifie.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Yes, with a ſafe Conſcience, I can ſwear it has coſt my Maſter—and me, above Thirty Shillings upon you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What did you Club with your Maſter then, Mr. Slouch?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Now and then, for a Flagon of Ale, an it pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh you ſhall be no Loſer, Friend—There's ſomething to defray your Expences— gives him Money.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Thank you kindly, Forſooth—Od, this 'tis to be Sharp—Now wou'd I give Sixpence to know if this be a good Guinea, or a Counter— aſide.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: As to your Charges, Mr. Num—If you pleaſe to give me a Bill, they ſhall be diſcharg'd—But for my Daughter, I have deſign'd her otherways.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p:
A Bill! I ſcorn your Words; I'm as well able, de you ſee, to ſpend Thirty Shillings as you, for ought I know; yet I'm not angry neither; only what makes me mad, is, that you ſhou'd think me ſuch a Fool to be fob'd off I know not
how—Why mun, all our Town knows that I'm to have her, and they have promis'd me the Bells ſhou'd Ring a whole Day—And now you'd have me go home with the Tale of a Tub, like a Dog that has loſt his Ears—What did you come bouncing to our Houſe for! and ſay I ſhou'd have your Daughter—I did not come after her, nor you neither mun.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: What I ſaid I thought at that time, Sir; but no Man can blame me for changing my Mind to Advantage in diſpoſing of my Child— I have a better Proſpect both in Birth and Eſtate, than you, or your Father can offer. Therefore I ſay without any Paſſion, I deſire you'd give your ſelf no farther Trouble about this matter, Mr. Num.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Birth, and Eſtate! What means my Father? how I tremble!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He has certainly heard of Sir Jeffry's Death, and deſigns to make thee Happy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Impoſſible! He was in the Minſter before us.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Birth, and Eſtate! Slouch, come hither Sirrah! han't my Father a Thouſand a Year?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Yes that he has, an more too: He has Ten hundred, I'll ſwear it.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: I believe he has, as you ſay, Slouch.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: An I am all the Children he has, am I not, Slouch?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Ay, all that he dares own, Sir.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Look ye there now! An I'll hold you a Bottle of Cyder that I'm as well born as he; my Father's Church-warden and Captain of the Militia, as 'tis known very well; and I'm call'd the Young Captain, ſo I am.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Aye, that every Body knows.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir, I have nothing to ſay to that, and am your humble Servant—Come Belinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I wiſh you a good Journey, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Captain, your Servant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: A murrain take your Fleer ——

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: You may go to London now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Go to London, go to the Devil! 'Slife I'll follow them mun, mehap he do's but joke; and Father will break my Head, becauſe I did not underſtand a Joke— Therefore come along, Slouch— Exit.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: ACT. II.
SCENE, Sir David Watchum's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Sir David into a Garden before the Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I Have ſurvey'd my Houſe round and round to Night, from Door to Door, and Gate to Gate— —He that wou'd keep a handſome Woman of Twenty thouſand Pound, muſt learn the Gameſter's Art, to live without Sleep—Methought, from my Garret Window, I ſaw a Man ſauntring about my Ground, and ſeem'd to pry too narrowly into my Houſe—It may be a Rogue—I would not loſe Mrs. Laura; for, if poſſible, ſhe ſhall fill no Arms but mine. I have kept her from the ſight of Man theſe twelve Months; and now I deſign to offer her Liberty, provided ſhe'll conſent to be my Wife; if ſhe refuſes, I'll have the Lights quite ſtop'd up, and ſhe ſhall not ſo much as ſee the Sun—Ha! who's here! Ho, 'tis Lucy, her Maid; I wiſh I cou'd make this Jade of my Intereſt—What the Vengeance do's ſhe do up ſo early?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: This old Fellow is certainly the Devil—One can go no where, but one is ſure to meet him.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What makes you here, ha Miſtreſs?—Now am I afraid of venturing to the Coffee-Houſe, tho' my Coach is at the Door.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Too much Sleep is unwholſome, you know Sir, by your own Rule; ſo hearing the Door open, I came down to breath the Morning Air.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: That you might have done at your Window; no, no, you have ſome Plot in hand now I warrant! Where's your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: In her Chamber. Where ſhou'd ſhe be?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: In her Bed wou'd be a fitter Place—Women of Virtue, that have no Intrigues, are faſt aſleep in their Beds at this time a-day

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: A ſleep! That's impoſſible in this Houſe—Pray how can any body ſ • eep, as long as you are awake; are you not rambling all Night; up Stairs, down Stairs, locking one Door, and opening another; heming, coughing, ſpitting, ſneezing, yawning, ſtamping, mutt'ring—One no ſooner ſhuts ones Eyes—but ſlap goes a Door, clatter goes a Key— down tumbles a Stool, bow wow goes the Dog—This is the conſtant Muſick you make, Sir: 'Slife, if one were a Slave in Turkey, one ſhou'd ſometimes reſt in quiet.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Good lack, good lack, all this I get for my care— —Why all this is for your Lady's good, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, if you call this Good! Then pray Sir employ your Study for the future, to do her ill Offices; for nothing can be more diſagreeable, than your preſent treatment both to my Lady and me.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Say you ſo! What, you don't like your way of living then? ha.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Not at all I aſſure you, Sir—Living! d'ye call it—We wou'd have Liberty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: You ſhall have Liberty, if your Lady is not her own Enemy——and for your part, if you pleaſe, you may ſerve your ſelf, and her, by being ſerviceable to me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Which way, pray Sir? For there is not many things I wou'd refuſe to procure my Lady, her dear, dear Liberty; pray inform me, I'm impatient to know it.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why thus—I have a very Cordial Affection for Mrs. Laura, out of pure Conſideration of her youth—I wou'd not have a young Woman fall into ill hands at firſt; therefore I deſign to marry her my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Heaven forbid! that wou'd be falling into ill hands indeed. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Now I wou'd have you break this matter to her; and ſecond it with all the force of Argument you are capable of—When we are married, you ſhall both take what Liberty you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why ſure a Perſon of your experienc'd Years, wou'd not be guilty of ſuch a Folly.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you call Folly? I had no Ch • ldren by my laſt Wife, and I wou'd willingly have an Heir to keep up my Name—and do you call this Folly?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Heirs! Why do you hope for an Heir of your own getting, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why not, pray?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What, upon ſuch a fine Woman as ſhe is—In my Conſcience, were I in your place, I ſhou'd dread being the erranteſt, you know what, in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Mrs. Pert! that's not your buſineſs, I ſhall dread no ſuch thing—All I deſire of you, is to tell her, my Eſtate, Prudence, Wiſdom and Temperance, out-weighs Youth, Folly, Titles, and Debauchery.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, for one that is in Love with her Grave. Certainly, Sir, you are not in your right Senſes—Why your Requeſt is ſo abominable, ſo vile, ſo ridiculous, and ſo unjuſt; that I wou'd not be concern'd in it for a thouſand Pounds— Indeed you have pitch'd upon the wrong Perſon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Dav.
sp.p: Say you ſo! Good lack—So I have pitch'd upon the wrong Perſon you ſay! ha! If I had deſir'd you to ſay your Prayers, I'll be hang'd, if I had not pitch'd upon the wrong Perſon too, Goſſip prate apace—but I'll hamper ye, I warrant you; I'll croſs your Deſigns, till I have finiſh'd my own —go, get out of my ſight.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, ſurely this Life won't laſt always. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: My Maſter ſtays at the Coffee-houſe, and has ſent me to ſurvey this Dome, and try to give Mrs. Laura's Maid notice of his Arrival; but how far I may be ſerviceable to him, I know not—Ha! who have we yonder? The old Guardian himſelf I doubt—So, he has found me—What the duce muſt I pretend now?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you want Friend, ha?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Good morrow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, Good morrow; what more?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I hope you are well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Yes, thank Heaven, Sir! what then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why then I am very glad of it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: You are very glad of it, Sir! Why what a Pox is my Health to you? Who are you? What are you? And from whence come you, ha Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, your Queſtions are ſo copious, that they require a conſiderable Study to anſwer: let me recollect a little—I have gone through ſo many Trades, that without my Diary (which I have not about me at preſent) I can't remember half of them; nor indeed can I tell how to ſtile my ſelf otherwiſe than an univerſal Man —The World is my Country; and for want of an Eſtate, I live by my Wits—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: A Rogue, I warrant him. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sometimes an honeſt Man, ſometimes a Knave; juſt as occaſions fall out.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ay! and you oftner happen to be a Knave, than an honeſt Man, I doubt, Friend.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why look ye, Sir, that is juſt as I abound, or want Money; for my preſent Profeſſion is Phyſick—Now when my Pockets are full, I cure a Patient in three Days— —when they are empty, I keep him three Months.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: An excellent Principle truly—But pray what is your buſineſs at my Houſe?—We are all in a good ſtate of health at preſent.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay no very great buſineſs, only I look'd in, as I paſs'd by, Sir, that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Now in my Opinion you have another Reaſon; for you have the Aſpect of one of thoſe Sparks that comes in at a Window, or down a Chimney at two in the Morning—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have a care what you ſay, Sir, I'm known very well not far off.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ay, too well perhaps! Zounds, Sir, what buſineſs have you here, ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A queer old Duke this—Why, Sir, if you muſt know, I am in ſearch of ſome Simples which I have occaſion for—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Simples!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Simples! A very ſimple Excuſe, ſaith—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, I have many Years practis'd Chymiſtry, and there's ſcarce any Diſeaſe incident to Humanity, but I have cur'd; Stone, Gravel, Spleen, Vapours, fits of the Mother, and ſo forth—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Rather Fits of the Father, I fancy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I had attain'd to ſuch perfections in the Chymical Art, that I wanted but one degree of heat to reach the Philoſopher's Stone.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: That Habit methinks does not anſwer this mighty Skill.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, Skill does not lie in Cloaths—And the moſt ingenuous, are not always the moſt fortunate— I have had many Croſſes in my time—Which has reduc'd me much below my Birth, I aſſure you—I ſerve an Officer at preſent, in the Quality of a Valet de Chambre, whoſe Life I ſav'd at the Battle of Audenard, when he was ſhot through with a Cannon Ball.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: How! ſhot through with a Cannon Ball?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; what, do you wonder at that? Why, Sir, I have a Water, that if your Head were off, I'd but waſh it with that, and clap it upon your Shoulders again; and you ſhou'd grow as perfectly well in half an hour, as ever you was in your Life; I have made the Experiment upon Thouſands; my Maſter's Brother was one of them—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: If you were in Petticoats, I ſhou'd take you for the Kentiſh Miracle—What is this Officer's Name, Friend, that you ſerve?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Captain Bounce, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Bounce! I fancy you are related to him, are you not, Friend?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, Sir, not at all; indeed he uſes me more like a Relation, than a Servant, for the reaſon before mentioned.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ha! And where is he, pray?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: At the Talbot, Sir; if you pleaſe I'll fetch him hither?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: By no means, Sir; but what buſineſs have you here in Peterborough?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We have been raiſing Recruits, Sir—A Pox of this old Dog; how many impertinent Queſtions does he aſk— Here's no hopes of ſeeing Lucy—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I deſire you'd look your Simples elſewhere; for I don't like you, notwithſtanding your fair Pretences.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall obey you—But pray who does this Houſe belong to?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why, this Houſe belongs to —its Maſter.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir——Pray who is that Maſter? if I may be ſo bold to ask.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why that Maſter is—a Man • Friend.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Really, Sir, your Anſwers are ſo conciſe and ſo ingenious, that it is impoſſible to quit your Company——We deſign for Cambridge to Night, pray what time do you think we ſhall get in?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav,
sp.p: The Town Clock will tell you, when you come there.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Is it poſſible!—I humbly thank you, Sir—— one thing more I wou'd gladly be reſolv'd—I have a Brother bound for Portugal; pray is the Wind fair, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you take me for, a Weather Cock, Sirrah? Heark ye, the Wind will blow you no good, if you don't get about your buſineſs, remember that, and ſo farewel. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very well——this muſt be Sir David his own ſelf— —'Egad he has all his Paces, it will be hard to bring matters about here; I'm juſt as wiſe as I was when I came—and have told fifty Lyes to no purpoſe——Ha! his Coach at the Door, I'll watch whither he goes, I'm reſolv'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What, are you not gone yet, Sirrah? I'll have you laid by the Heels, if you don't get off my ground this moment.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, I am going this moment—A Pox of his Leathern Jaws —Well, I'll inform my Maſter what has paſs'd, and leave him to think on what's to come— Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: So, he is gone—I don't like the Countenance of this Fellow—Sam—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Lock my Doors, d'ye hear; till I return from
the Coffee-houſe, let no body in or out—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I ſhall obſerve, Sir. Ex. ſeverally.

div.head: SCENE Changes to the Coffee-houſe, Lovely, Conſtant, and Faithful.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I have confirm'd the whole Town in the belief of thy Father's Death.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Then thou haſt done me Service—Come, you'll both go with me to Truſty's—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: No, I have a mind to ſtay here; to ſee if Sir David comes; this Morning I will try to get acquainted with him; perhaps my being a Stranger, he may invite me to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, He wou'd as ſoon give thee his Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! Manage, what News? Haſt thou ſeen Lucy?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, Sir, but I have ſeen the Knight.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, and what have you diſcover'd?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That it was not worth your while to come Poſt from London, to return the ſame way—Ah Pox of the laſt Horſe I rid; what a curſed Fall had I in Stangate-hole— —don't you remember, Sir, how I lay over Head and Ears in Mire; whilſt the Gentlemen of the Pad diſburthen'd you of a hundred Pounds?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Hang your unſeaſonable Memory, Sirrah; leave fooling, and tell me—You ſee Sir David, did you ſpeak to him?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but he anſwer'd me with a damn'd ſowre Air; and I aſſure you it will require Cannon to reduce his Cittadel.

sp.speaker: Faith,
sp.p: Love has taught me to ſurmount all Difficulties.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But here the Knight will be immediately; for I heard him give Orders to lock up the Doors, till he return'd from the Coffee-houſe.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ay, that's right Sir David! ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Lock up the Doors! Ah poor Laura! how ſhall I give thee notice of my being here—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p:
I have a thought in my Head, if it cou'd be put in
practice——Heark, I hear the Coach——had here's no b •
dy in the Room to diſcover the Trick——Let as pretend a Quarrel——Draw, Faithful.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: To what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: You ſhall know inſtantly——Lovely, do you ſeem to part us; he's here——Damn you Sir, you Lye. draw • . I have not loſt, nor will I pay——

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Take your Lye back, Sir, ſeem to fight.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, Gentlemen; what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Damn you, Sir, you ſhall pay me—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: There is the Money then, you have it——pretend to be wounded with that Thruſt, Faithful. Aſide to him.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am wounded——pray help to lead me home—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh Friend! what have you done?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What's here, Murder?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I hope the Wound's not mortal——Curſe on my unlucky Arm; how doſt thou, Ned?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Do quotha! If the Gentleman is wounded, I muſt ſecure you, Sir,

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Secure me, Sir! Alas! Sir, I don't intend to fly; a Pox of all Wagers I ſay.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Pray lead me to my Inn, for I feel my Spirits very faint.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Lead you! Alas, I doubt you cannot walk ſo far.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What, is there not a Chair or a Coach to be got?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir David has a Coach at the Door, if you cou'd prevail with him to lend it you a little.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Sir, pray oblige us with your Coach, it ſhall return immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: With all my heart— Goes to the Door, and ſpeaks to his Coachman aloud.
Tom, Here, carry this Gentleman home—d'ye hear, and make haſte back again,

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Oh! Friend, I underſtand you now; my Soul dances with the bare Idea.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: It has ſucceeded to my Wiſh—Lovely, help l •• d him to the Coach.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: If there be any Danger, Mr. Lovely, take care to ſecure the Murderer.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh! They are intimate Friends, Sir David, he won't flinch, I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, well, look you to that— Ex. into the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Manage! Come you along with us, I have ſome Inſtructions for you. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE Changes to the out ſide of Truſty's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Lovely, Conſtant, Clinch and Manage.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He'll certainly get admittance to his Miſtreſs by this Stratagem; but if the Knight ſhou'd find him there, how will he come off?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Nay, let him look to that—but Manage ſhall take Clinch's great Coat, 'tis like a Livery—Sweet Sir, can you condeſcend to wear a Livery an hour or two?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To ſerve my Maſter's Amour I will, Sir—elſe I ſcorn a Livery—. I muſt have that black Wig too.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Well, well! Here, Clinch, change, change with him. they change Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: So, Sir! Now I am your Valet de Chambre.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what am I to do now?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Why, go watch about Sir David's Door, and as you ſee occaſion, employ your Wits.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, let me alone for that; your humble Servant, Gentlemen. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Dolly, out of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Oh! Are you come Captain; I have told my Miſtreſs every particular—pleaſe to walk in, Sir, I'll inform my Maſter you are here. They go in.

div.head: The SCENE draws, and diſcovers them in a Room.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis an admirable Project, Captain, if you are not diſcover'd; but your Father will certainly know it in a little time.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: If poſſible, I'll marry the Woman to Night.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I fear Sir Jeffrey will reſent the Trick.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I hope to convince him the Trick was upon Truſty; for he may recover the Money of him, if he pleaſes, and with me it may paſs for his Daughter's Portion; but rather than fail, I'll give the Steward my Bond, when 'tis diſcover'd, to refund the Money, when I become Maſter of my Father's Eſtate; for without Belinda, nothing can make me Happy.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, you'll ſcarce find a Man in the Army of your Mind—Prefer a Woman to Money! Why Sir, Money is the very Hinge the whole World turns upon——A Soldier, and not love Money!—Money has power to alter all Conſtitutions, and in ſpight of Cuſtom, ſtamp what Form it pleaſes—'Twill make an honeſt Man a Knave; nay, 'twill make a Knave an honeſt Man—'Twill make a Coward Valiant—an Old Woman Young——a Young Woman a Saint ——a Lawyer Juſt—a Stateſman Loyal——and a Courtier keep his Word.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Clinch is a Wit.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Faith, I always thought ſo by my Poverty.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Well hinted Clinch——I'm in thy Debt——

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I'm yours in all reſpects—Oh! this dear Colour!
sp.l: What can there be that this dear Coin can't buy?
For thee Men toil and ſweat, ſwear, cheat and lye;
For thee do's Friend his deareſt Friend betray,
And Women give their very Souls away.
Joyn but Ambition to this glitt'ring Evil,
And in an Inſtant Man is made a Devil.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ha, ha. ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ad's heart, Sir, ſet your weeping Face in Order— Here comes the Steward—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Captain Conſtant, your Servant! you are welcome into the Country. What, you are in want of Men; I warrant you are going to raiſe Recruits.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Not at this time, Sir; 'tis a more unwelcome Accident that brought me down. takes out his Handkerchief, and ſeems to weep.

sp.speaker: Truſt.
sp.p: Good lack! the News is really true then, Sir Jeffry is Dead.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, poor Gentleman, he's laid low—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I confeſs I heard ſo, but I hop'd it might be Report only; I did deſign to have ſet out for London as ſoon as I had D • n'd—My Heart akes—Bleſs me! What have I paid him without any Receipt—I lov'd Sir Jeffry like a Brother; truly I am very much troubled— ſeems to weep.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Grief is very catching, I find; it makes me weep too —Be comforted, Sir to Conſtant. Fathers muſt go as well as Sons—Why do you afflict your ſelf at this • ate, Sir? Since Death is Death, who can help it?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pray be comforted, Sir John— to Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Pray of what Diſtemper did he die?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah! duce on't! What was that hard Word? Now can't I think on't, as I hope to be Great—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Of an Apoplexy—A Pox of the Doctors, for giving Death ſo many ſtrange Names. aſide.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Right, Sir—He died of Apoplexy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Of an Apoplexy! Why then I doubt he died ſuddainly.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: In a Moment's time, Sir, he was alive and dead—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, without ever ſpeaking one Word, Sir —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Roars out. Oh, oh, oh. Did he ſettle his Affairs in his Health? Did he make any Will?—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Not any, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: No, Sir: He has left all at ſixes and ſevens.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh— faints.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! Help, Clinch, I hope he is not Dead.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: No, no; he breaths, thank Heaven; pray you look up, Sir.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Why are you thus concern'd?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You really increaſe Sir John's Grief, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh what have I loſt!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I know you have loſt a Friend in my Father; but you ſhall find him again in me.

sp.speaker: Tru,
sp.p: Oh but he has left all things at fixe • and ſe ••• s, Clinch ſays—Did he ſay nothing to you about me before he dy'd?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Not a Syllable—But I ſuppoſe your Concern proceeds from having paid him M • ney without any thin •• ſhow for it under his hand.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, there's my Misfortune— Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: 'Tis the Money, not the Man—Let not that trouble you, Sir, my young Maſter has been inform'd to a Farthing what it was —Tell him, tell him, Sir, your Father appear'd, and let me alone to clinch it. aſide to Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Inform'd!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Yes Mr. Truſty; my Father cou'd not reſt till 〈◊〉 had diſclos'd your Affair.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah good honeſt Soul; ſeeing he was ſnatch'd away ſo ſuddainly he has ſeveral times appear'd.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How! appear'd, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Aſk my Maſter elſe.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Moſt certain, Sir—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p:
He haunted us ſix Days like the Devil; ſometimes like a ſhag Dog—Sometimes like a white Pidgeon —At laſt he took his own Shape. Clinch, ſaid he, don't you know me? Then addreſſing himſelf to my Maſter; don't be afra •• , ſaid he, I come to tell you, that at ſeveral times I have ••
ceiv'd from Mr. Trusty.—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ah dear Ghoſt, dear Ghoſt; how much did he ſay •

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Eight hundred Pound.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Right to a Penny, look ye there now, ſee what it is to deal with honeſt Men; one loſes nothing by them, tho' 〈◊〉 their Graves.

sp.speaker: Clin,
sp.p: Oh, the Dead, Sir, are always Generous; they value Money no more than that— ſnapping his Finger • .

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman, that he ſhou'd take a Journey ſic • the other World upon my account.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, the Dead ride poſt upon the Winds— He charg'd me to tell you, for your Satisfaction, he wou • d come and give you an Acquittance himſelf.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By no means, I am content, let the Dead viſit wh • they will for me.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Oh fear not, Sir, he'll not trouble you; but to out Buſineſs, Sir, what you have paid I will diſcount.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And the reſt of the Money is at your Service, and my Daughter too, Sir John, if you have not loſt the Remembrance of her.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: To ſhow you that I have not, Mr. Truſty, I aſſure you ſhe will be the welcomeſt Preſent of the two.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Thy Buſineſs is done, Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir John! Well, I'll fetch the Writings, and diſpatch ſome Affairs, and then I'll carry you to my Daughter—But upon ſecond Thoughts, pleaſe to walk into my Study, 'tis more convenient.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: With all my Heart, I'll follow you— Exit Truſty.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Matters go as you cou'd wiſh; you'll be Married to Night, Captain.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I wiſh 'twere over; Egad I'd rather fight half a dozen Men, than deſcend to this Raſcally way of Lying, were there any help for i • , it is beneath a Soldier—
sp.l: A Soldier ſcorns the whining Lover's Art;
His Courage takes Poſſeſſion of the Heart:
Diſdains by Treachery to raiſe his Name,
But boldly owns the bright ambitious Flame,
And courts his Miſtreſs as he courts his Fame.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE, Truſty in his Study, with Conſtant, Lovely and Clinch. Papers and Money upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: THere, Sir John, there are in theſe Bags Two and twenty hundred Pound, which, with the Eight hundred I remitted Sir Jeffry, is juſt Three thouſand Pound; if you pleaſe you may count it, 'tis moſt in Gold.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: No, I'll take your Word f • r • t • here, 〈…〉 to Drive the Carrier, he is juſt now going to 〈◊〉 ; Ord •• him where to pay it in, d'ye heat?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—— Exit with the Bags.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He is loaden with it, ha, ha, ha.——

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Poor Sir Jeffry, reſt his Soul, did promiſe to ha • e me Twenty Pound a Year; for I have paid him Two hundred Pounds a Year theſe ſixteen Years, for that Land which is not worth an Hundred and fourſcore.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Mr. Truſty? Then you muſt perform your Father's Promiſe, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p:
Ay, when he has paid me as much as he has my F •
ther.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come, ſhall I ſettle Matters between you? Advance Sir John a Hundred Pounds; you know he has been kept ſhort, and doubtleſs •• s •• caſion for ready Money, and he ſhall 'bate you Twenty Pound a Year.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh, that's all one, Mr. L ••• ly——I can't do that.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, ſince Mr. Lovely has propos'd it, if you won't do that—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, but Sir John, perhaps you'll expect a large Fortune with my Daughter; I can't tell how to——

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I aſk you for none, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why then there's the Hundred Pound; but you muſt ſignifie at the bottom of this Leaſe our Bargain.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Give it me, I'll do't— ſits down to write.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Morrow Landlord, I ha' brought you a little Rent, and in froth 'tis but a little neither; for we ha' had but ſorr • Crop of Barley, and the Crows, a murrain take 'em, ha' eat up all my Beans, I think.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But you have a new Landlord, Roger. Old Sir Jeffry is dead, and there's his Son.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Maſter! Bleſs you, Sir, I did not know your Father, not I, tho' I have paid him many a fair Pound —Nor I dan't know you; but an you be my Landlord, I'm an honeſt Man; and tho' I ſay it, pay my Rent 〈◊〉 well as any Body.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I don't doubt it, Friend—I am ſorry your Harveſt has not prov'd ſo good as you expected.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I hope, Maſter, for Luck's ſake now, you'll 'bate me ſomething of my Rent.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I can't do that, Roger—For the Taxes take away all my Money—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, as you ſay, Maſter, theſe Taxes are ſad things, that's the Truth on't —Od they find out ſtrange ways; they had got a Trick here once to make one pay for one's Head—Mercy on us, I was afraid they wou'd make one pay for one's Tail too—My Neighbour What de call um —ſays it coſt him the Lord knows what in Buryings and Chriſtnings—Adod 'tis a ſore Thing, a Man muſt pay for Lying with his own Wife.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, 'twas a Grievance indeed; but Taxes can't be help'd, ſo long as the Wars continue.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Wars! Why what need there be any Wars? Can't People live peaceably and quietly among themſelves—If they will ſquable, and play the Rogue, let 'em go to Law,; can't they ſet the Lawyers to work; I warrant they'll quickly make them as quiet as Lambs.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; but we are at Wars with a Prince that cares for no Laws but his own, nay he breaks them too, when 'tis his Intereſt—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why then Mercy upon us, I ſay—Well an how! may one wiſh you much Joy? Ha, you got a Wife, Landlord? By the Meſs you are a pretty Man—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I'm not ſo happy yet, Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Good lack, I'm ſorry for't—Why now here's Maſter Truſty has a good▪ ſweatly look'd▪ Gentlewoman to his Daughter—What think you of her, Landlord?—Od, and all Parties were agreed, ſhe'd make a rare Bedfellow, I'm perſuaded.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I believe Sir John is of your mind; have you any Intereſt with her, Father?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Not I, in troth, Maſter Lovely—but the Gentlewoman is of a ſweet temper.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Do you think you cou'd perſuade her to run away with him?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd, Sir —for a pretty Woman i • the beſt Luggage in the World—for when a Man in w •• ry, he may reſt upon it; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: You are waggiſh, Roger.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Roger will joke; there's your Acquittance, if Sir John pleaſe to ſign it—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: 'Tis the ſame thing if you ſign it, Mr. Truſty.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: I find my Daughter ſigns the Note. ſtands fair in your Opinion, Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir—I hope you ar'n't angry! I meant no harm—I ſpoke as I thought; an I had a hundred Daughters —my Landlord, and Mr. Lovely, ſhould have them all, and they wou'd, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you truly.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh! a hundred wou'd be too many.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Prithee haſt thou never a ſingle one at preſent?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Not that I know of, in troth, Sir; but an you'll do me a ſmall kindneſs, Sir, I may chance get you one about fourteen Years hence.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That will be ſomething too long to ſtay.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: But what can I ſerve thee in, Roger?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Why, Mrs. Belinda has a kind of a Maid c • ll'd
•• r •• in, I have had a hankering mind after her theſe two Y • ars, 〈◊〉 the ſliving Baggage will not come to a Reſolution yet.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: You muſt apply your ſelf to my Daughter, Roger, ſhe'll be the beſt Advocate; but I doubt ſhe's to 〈◊〉 for you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Too fine! nay, nay, I'll never quarrel • ith 〈…〉 that; an ſhe can win Gold, as the Saying is, 〈◊〉 let her wear it.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: But I doubt you are not fine enough for her.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Mehap ſo, as y • u ſay; indeed I have you ſuch • ay Cloaths as theſe Gentlefolk have, becauſe I can't afford it, do ye ſee? elſe I ſhou'd like 'em well enough—In troth, I believe I have ſome Seeds of a Gentleman in me; for methinks now I like broad Cloath better than my Leathern Breeches; and a Holland Shirt, far before a Hempen one——adod methinks, I, I, I, cou'd be well enough contented with a Bottle of Wine every day—I am m • inly inclin'd to ſtrong Beer— and don't care a Farthing i • I never were to drink any ſmall.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh! extraordinary Symptoms of a Gentleman, I'll aſſure you—Well, we'll ſpeak to Dolly for you.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we'll all ſpeak for you; go, go into the Cellar then, and drink thy Belly full.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Be ſure to drink Dolly's Health.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Thank you kindly, Sir—Ay, ay, Maſter, that I will I promiſe you, in a full Horn—So Landlord, good by to you with all my heart Exit.

sp.speaker: Truſt.
sp.p: Now, Sir John, I'll ſend my Daughter to keep you Company, till I look for ſome Leaſes your Father order'd me to get drawn, which if you think fit to ſign—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: If the Tenants are able Men, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Truſty,
sp.p:
Oh! very ſufficient Men, Sir John.
Ex. Truſty.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, thou haſt ſecur'd the Money, Conſtant; and my Advice is to diſpatch the Woman, as faſt as you can, and find ſome pretence to defer theſe Leaſes for two or three days—Sir Jeffrey is whimſical, and if he ſhou'd alter his mind, and come down—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Here wou'd be no ſtaying for me, if he ſhou'd; therefore I deſign to be as quick as poſſible—but here comes the Star that guides me to Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And my Pilot—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What Voyage are you for, pray?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The everlaſting Voyage of Matrimony, Child— and your Eyes are two ſuch dangerous Rocks, that nothing. • ut your Tongue can ſteer me into Harbour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But any of my Sex can ſteer you out, you'll be for croſſing from Port to Port, to make that everlaſting Voyage agreeable.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, faith, where I drop my Anchor, there my Veſſe • is moor'd for Life—Well, Conſtant, what ſays the Lady? will ſhe let thy Habeas Corpus remove her?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Out of one Priſon into another, is it not ſo, Conſtant?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Interrogating! nay then 'tis proper to be alone; there is a very pretty Collection of Prints in the next Room, Madam, will you give me leave to explain them to you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Any thing that may divert your Love Subject. Ex.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Can Belinda term my Arms a Priſon?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But Marriage is a Better, Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I'll not make it one; I'm a true Britiſh Subject, I'm for Liberty and Property—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And Self-intereſt, for they are inſepara • l • .

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I hope our Intereſts are the ſame, and when l • nk' • , will be the ſtronger. C • me, Madam, con •• d • r our opportutunity may be ſhort, we ought to be quick, to prevent diſcovery; I have your Father's conſent.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Diſcovery! Why what is a 〈…〉 but reaſonable I be let into the Secret, if I'm in danger of •• ating the Puniſhment, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Why that Sir John, Belinda? I know you are inform'd of all, then 〈…〉 ridicule my 〈…〉 my Love for you that firſt inſpir'd me with this Stratagem; then prithee come, my deareſt—— taking h • r ha • d.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Not a ſtep, ſweet Servant—I'll know 〈…〉 terms I capitulate, e'er I ſurrender.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Terms! Madam! Has not Dolly told you of the Plot?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, upon your Father and mine. Captain, but I don't think it ſafe to join in it: Suppoſe my Father be • bl • g •• to pay back this Money; may not that be provocation enough to diſown me? and i • your's ſhou'd for this trick diſinherit you?—What Joynture can you make me?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: My Heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pſhaw! that is the ſlippery'ſt piece in all Fortune's Treaſure—we never can be certain of that— —

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Then my Soul.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Where ſhall I find it? the Learned c • n't agree where to place it; therefore I'll have no trouble ab • ut th •• .

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Then take my Body for Bail, that I'm ſure is forth coming.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay, but there's No—No exeat Regnum in Love's Court—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: To cut off all Objections, I ſettle this Money upon you; and either put it out to Intereſt, or purchaſe ſome pretty Retirement; where, if Belinda loves but half ſo well, as I flatter'd my ſelf ſhe did, I can forſake all Courts and Company—and prefer a Grott with Her, before all the trappings of the Fools of Fortune—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Generouſly ſaid! I have try'd thee, Conſtant; and find thy Nature like thy Name; there, take my Hand— my Heart was thine before.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: 'Tis ſympathy of Souls that join us two,
Death only ſhall our Gordian Knot undo.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Until that Hour, Belinda will be true.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Joy to thee, my Friend; and you, Madam, we overheard your Proteſtations—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Prithee let's fetch the Parſon this Minute—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To chooſe—Ladies, we'll return inſtantly. Ex.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Proſperity to Belinda!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dare not you bear me Company, Girl?
Have you the Heart to let me run this Hazard alone?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, what wou'd you have me do?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Even what I deſign to do—Marry—for I'm ſure thou lov'ſt that hanſome young Fellow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I find you underſtand your own Conſtitution, Belinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So well; that if you follow my Example, you'll act as reſolutely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thine is a raſh Venture, if Sir Jeffrey ſhou'd not forgive him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The more honourable; we have Love, and that's the beſt Eſtate in a married Life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: True, but what can we poor Women do, whoſe Parents are not inclin'd to gratifie our Wiſhes;—you know mine are ſet againſt this Match—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pugh, Parents will relent in time—If not, Mr. Lovely has Fortune enough to make you happy—You love him, and he loves you; were I in your place, I'd fain ſee a third ſhou'd part us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: True, I do love him—but will not marry him, without a Portion; he ſhall never throw that in my Diſh, I reſolve.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
An admirable Reſolution truly—Then you'll go on; hang your Head, croſs your Arms, ſigh your Soul into the Air—ſit up all Night like a Watch Candle, and diſtil
your Brains through your Eye-lids—for ſo I have done— no, no, Girl, e'en let us ſave our T •• rs t • ll 〈…〉
• arried.

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.p: What, you think like moſt Wives, we ſhall have occaſion for them then, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: As it may fall out—Then let us marry whil • t we are young, that we may be able to bear it with the better Courage—But here's my Father over head and ears in Papers; I tremble though, to think what he will ſay when he finds the Cheat.

div.stage: Enter Truſty, with Papers in his hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And ſee who is behind him—— Enter Num and Slouch.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I have a ſudden thought how to divert my Father's Anger; when all's diſcover'd, I'll put it in practice—— Sir, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Od, She ſpeaks, Slouch——Nay, Madam, I'm your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Ha! what's that—Why, Sir, I admire—hey day, where are the Gentlemen, Daughter?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Sir, why here is one Gentleman; indeed I can't ſay much for Slouch—

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Why don't you anſwer me, ha?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I know not, Sir, they went out ſoon after we entred.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They whiſper'd, Sir, and left the Room.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Ha! I don't like that—

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p:
Mehap they are gone to fight for Mrs. Belinda. A • ſhe'd marry you, Maſter now, how rarely they'd be • h •
〈◊〉 ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Od, ſo they wou'd, as you ſay, Slouch——Madam, what ſay you? Mr. Truſty, ſhall we make an end on't? I know you are a merry Man, and did but joke wo' me.

sp.speaker: Truſty:
sp.p: Say you ſo! I doubt you won't find it ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: No! why I verify believe the Gentlewoman has • kindneſs for me, by her Looks; how ſay you, Miſtreſs? ſpeak the Truth, and ſhame the Devil, as the ſaying is— han't you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, if I muſt ſpeak the Truth, 'Squire, I have as much kindneſs for you, as for any body; my Father commanded me to love.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Ay! why what ſay you to Sir John Conſtant? don't you like him better?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I did once, Sir, but I don't remember I ever had your Conſent in that.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: You have it now then—'tis time enough; it is good to know what one has to truſt to.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Leave now, Sir, comes too late, he may have chang'd his Mind.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: No, no, you ſhall be married to Night, he ſhan't have time to think of Change.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, fair and ſoftly—he ſhall not have her to Night, mehap—for all your haſte; Slouch, ſtand by me.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: That I will, Maſter, in any Ground in England.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Humph! I gueſs her drift— Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then 'tis time for me to think on't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Hey day, What's here now!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I don't like Marches huddled up in haſte; and I learnt from your Inſtructions, Sir, to conſult my future Happineſs in a Marry'd State.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Good again, I'faith, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Your future Hapineſs why what can croſs your future Happineſs, Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: What, will they quarrel about me now, Slouch, ha?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: The Woman has a woundy mind to you, I ſee that, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Sir John •
Carriage is more looſe and familiar than formerly—from which I draw this Concluſion, Sir; that he thinks his Quality may now command, and when a Lover loſes reſpect, his Sincerity quickly follows. I like not the method of our Quality—The Name of Husband without the Fonddneſs, is like a Title without an Eſtate, of no value with the Wiſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am of her Opinion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: And I too, faith—Od, ſhe talks rarely; I ſhall have her, I find—In my Conſcience I love her ten times the better, becauſe I ſee ſhe loves me—and let me tell you, Sir, your Daughter is honester than you are—Why ſhou'd you pretend to croſs her Will? You plainly see, ſhe has a mind to no body but me—Mun—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I plainly ſee you are a Fool, and ſhe's another—

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Look ye, ſay what you will o' me, but don't affront her; for all you • re her Father, I won't let my Wife be call • d Names, de ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Zounds, get out of my Doors.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Ay, but who is the Fool then?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pray be calm; ſince you once lik'd the 'Squire for a Son-in-law, I hope I ſhan't diſoblige you in preferring him before Sir John for a Huſband.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Diſoblige him! Who cares if it d •• s, M • dam, 〈◊〉 along—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha, ha. If thy Father ſhou'd take thee at thy Word, Belinda?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Stars forbid—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee ſuch a provoking Creature?
Oh, Sir John, 'Tis well you are come—Where have you been? You are in danger of loſing your Miſtreſs here.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, I have taken the beſt way to ſecure her.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If the Parſon can do it, for we have got him in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: To Conſtant. Humour what I ſay—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Now Miſtreſs, You had beſt bring your Objections again, and ſpoil your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: To Num. If you dare maintain your Ch •• m to me. I am yours— I ſay again, Sir. I like the 'Squire beſt.

sp.speaker: Num.
