sp.p: Dare! od I, I, I, I, dare a, a.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What dare you do, Sir?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: What a Plague do you ſtare at ſo?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What was that you mutter'd! what dare you do?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: I dare do as much as you dare do—What a Po • . I'm not to be frighted wi' Looks, mun.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Od, take heed Maſter, he has a woundy long Sword.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: A Sword! I care not a—for his Sword, nor him neither. Walks about in a heat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Sir John, this Gentleman is a Perſon whom I eſteem.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and one that She intends to marry too.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Marry! when, Sir?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: When ſhe pleaſes, Sir; now, an you'll lend us your Parſon?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis fit you aſk him leave indeed!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I'll lend you my Sword in your Guts firſt.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Your Sword in my Guts—Slouch, give me your Cudgel. Snatches his Stick.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Ads blead, clear the way, clear the way; I'll turn the 'Squire looſe to any Man in Zomerſetſhire.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Come, out with your Spit, mun—Wounds, an I don't make ye put it up again, I'll ne'er ſtrike ſtroke more.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: The Devil, he'll knock me down. Lays his hand on his Sword.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Oh don't draw, Sir John—lay down your Stick, Sir, and get you about your buſineſs, or you'll oblige me to uſe you worſe than I am willing to do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Excellent Sport, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Incomparable, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Who cou'd have thought the Lout ſo couragious— —Oh pray let us have no fighting.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: You have had your Anſwer, Sir, therefore pray be gone quietly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You 'fright me out of my Wits, 'Squire; pray go out of my Father's Houſe peaceably; if you love me, do, we'll find ſome other way.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Love ye, yes, I do love you; or what makes me in ſuch a Paſſion, think you? Well, well, I will go out— Look ye, Sir, an you be a Man, follow me; I'll box fairly with you now, for half a Crown, and this Gentleman ſhall hold Stakes, and ſee fair play—If you dare now?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Fie, fie, 'Squire, Gentlemen don't uſe to Box.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Box, ye Blockhead, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Blockhead!—Zounds, I'll learn you to call Names.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Come on, Sirrah, I'll fight with you at the ſame time— begins to ſtrip I'll ſtand by Maſter, for the honour of Zomerſetſhire.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Death, you ſhamble ham'd Dog! I'll beat your Head off— Gives him a box of the Ear.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Ay! are you there? faith, come on—come on.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hold, hold, two to one is odds. parts them.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Let me alone, Sir, egad I'll fight'em both.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what do you do, 'Squire, fight with a Footman! pray leave off, or you'll diſoblige me for ever.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Oh Lord, oh Lord! what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: What care I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, don't you care for your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but I won't be made a Fool on; but I will go—an I were ſure you wou'd not be forc'd to marry this ſame Spark—I won't leave you in the lurch, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, no, 'Squire, they ſhall not force me, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Then I go—but look to't, an I catch you out of this Houſe; by the Maſs I'll rib you. Ex.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Adod, I was out of all Patience with the Fool— Come, take her by the hand, Sir John, you ſhall be married this Minute, we'll ſettle buſineſs afterward.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you'll repent this haſty Match.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What means Belinda?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You ſhall know within.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Get along —in my Soul, I think the whole Compoſition of Women is Contradiction. Ex. omnes.

div.head: SCENE Sir David's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: There, honeſt Coachman, drink my Health; but pray can't I ſpeak with the Gentlewoman of the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Sir David has no Wife, Sir; but here is a young Lady, I'll call her Maid; Mrs. Lucy, Mrs. Lucy, here is a Gentleman wou'd ſpeak with your Miſtreſs—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: A Gentleman! bleſs me, how came you to let a Man in, Thomas, in Sir David's abſence?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Sir David bad me himſelf, or you may be ſure I had not done it— I thank you, Sir. Ex. Coachman.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What do I ſee? Mr. Faithful!

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: The ſame! How fares my Love, my deareſt Laura? Quick, bring me to her, I am impatient till I ſee her.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, ſhe wou'd be as impatient as you, if ſhe
knew you were here —But by what Miracle did you prevail with Sir David?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Prithee ask no Queſtions—I'll inform thy Lady; haſte, my time's but ſhort, therefore muſt improve it.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, follow me then. Ex.

div.head: The SCENE draws, and diſcovers Mrs. Laura at her Spinet.
div.stage: After the Song, Enter Lucy and Faithful.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What did that Blockhead bawl ſo for, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: To have an Acquaintance of yours admitted, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: An Acquaintance of mine!——ha! my dear Faithful! am I awake? and is it really he?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: My deareſt Love— run into one another's Arms. Oh let me hold thee here for ever, for ever taſte the Nectar on theſe Lips——There is ſtill the ſame Fragrancy, as when we parted laſt.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh! it was a fatal parting—ſay my Love, how cam'ſt thou here? for the old Monſter allows no Mortal to viſit me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: By Stratagem, my Dear; he ſent me hither in his Coach, yet knows not I am come; thou ſhal't have the Story at more convenient leiſure; but now let us employ our time to advantage.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Heavens! how I tremble! he'll ſoon be back, for he's never out above half an Hour—Lucy, watch below. Ex. What can this ſhort interview avail us? which way ſhall I get out of his power? The nauſeous Goat told Lucy he deſign'd to marry me himſelf—and caſts ſuch loving Looks every time he ſees me, that I am half diſtracted, leſt he ſhou'd give his horrid Paſſion vent.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! Confound his Paſſion with himſelf—— conſent to fly with me to a Friend's Houſe in Town, where we'll be married, and put it out of his Power to confine thee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: With all my heart—My Priſon is ſo odious to me, I need but ſmall intreaties to make me quit it —this is the Cloſet he keeps my Writings in; if we cou'd contrive to get them along with us, or he'll give us trouble enough to get 'em out of his hands, here—don't you think one might wrinch it open?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: So he may proſecute us for a Robbery.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Let him, I'll meddle with 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Oh, Madam! there's S • r David
〈…〉
• ent Paſſion, beating all the Servants in before him.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Undone! What ſhall I • s;ay • what will become of thee?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
Sink the Villain—h •• e 〈…〉 Deare ••
▪ take no thought for me; ſeem not to know me; pretend ſurprize, and beg me to be gone; leave the reſt to me.

div.stage: Enter Sir David, beating his Men in upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sir. Dav.
sp.p: Ye Dogs, what have ye done, ha?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: What do you beat me for? Did you not bid me carry him home?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Zounds, not to my home▪ ye Raſcal. bea ••
〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: What do you mean, Madam, by ſaying you don't know me; 'ſdeath, did not I lodge here laſt Night?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: How's this? how's this?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, I never ſaw you before; neither do we let Lodgings, then pray be anſwer'd.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: A very pretty trick, ſaith▪ What, have you a m ••• to cheat me of 〈◊〉 Ho ••• s, and my P • rtman •• a • —Look ye, Madam, this won't paſs upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: No, nor upon me, neither, Sir.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, your humble Servant; I think I have had the Honour to ſee you ſomewhere. I am in diſpute with this Gentlewom • n here; ſhe'd fain perſwade me I have muſt 〈◊〉 my Inn, — —and that I did not lie here laſt Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Lye here! Why, do you take this Lady for an Hoſteſs, 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, ſhe is very handſome—but why the Devil muſt • eauty make her deny her Calling—Ad, you Country Gentlemen, do ſo kiſs and flatter your Landladies, that egad, they don •• know where their Tails hang—but we make them know th • mſelves in London—Once more, will you call your Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! ye Dogs, I'll be reveng'd on you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The Fault's not mine, Sir; Tomas bad me let him in.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
What no Attendance yet? So, he, T • pſter, Chamberlain — —Pray Sir ſit down— I w • rr • nt I • ll •• ke 〈◊〉
Body hear—Heark ye, you Miſtreſs—You are not above your Buſineſs too, are you? to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, I ſhall go diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Pray Sir know your way out, don't think I'm one of your Wenches.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Good lack, ha, ha, what are you a fine Lady too? the Devil! Sure this is a Bawdy-houſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I dare ſwear you'd make it one if you cou'd—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, I take this for an extraordinary Inn—Pray do me the favour to ſit—I'll beat the Chamber down, but I'll make ſome Body come up. So, ho, the Houſe here—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: A plague ſplit you, what do you make all this Noiſe for? oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Pray, Sir David, humour the Gentleman, for I fancy he is a little beſide himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Humour the Devil! Hell and Furies! This muſt be ſome Rogue—Here, where are you Raſcals?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ay Scoundrels, where are you? Ye Dogs, what is the reaſon we can have no Attendance? Strikes one of them. Fetch us a Bottle of Claret, Sirrah, and bring us word what we can have to Eat—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Bring a Bottle of Claret! bring a Halter— What do you ſtrike my Servants for? ha, Sir.

sp.speaker: Faith,
sp.p: Your Servants, Sir! They are my Servants, as long as I pay for what I call for—Ho! I find you are the Landlord of this well-govern'd Inn—Make your People more tractable, de you hear, Sir? Or I ſhall not only beat them, but you too——Death ye Villains, why don't you ſtir?Strikes another.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What will be the end of this? All my Comfort lies in his Aſſurance—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Zounds, let him ſtir if he dares—Get out of my Houſe, Sirrah, or I'll lay you by the Heels; don't put your Shams upon us—Don't Bully here; I thought you was wounded when I lent you my Coach—But I find you are a Rogue, and either deſign'd to Rob my Houſe, or
Raviſh this Lady—Fetch me a Conſtable 〈◊〉 the Devil! I'll Box with you, if you're for Boxing——Get into that Room Laura, I'll deal with him I warrant ye. Put •
Laura in.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh unfortunate! How ſhall I ever ſee him agen?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I'll be here about an Hour hence before this Door.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ay! But to what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I thought you was wounded when I lent you my Coach.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Wounded, Sir! why ſo I am, and my Wounds bleed afreſh with Vexation— —Was it your Coach! I and I was miſtaken then, you are not my Landlord; I ask your pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Rot your Pardon—How now, who the Devil are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am this Gentleman's Servant—Bleſs me, Sir, what do you do here? Why Sir John and Mr. Lovely has been ſearching all the Town for you; they brought a Surgeon to the Talbot, and not finding you there, nor no where elſe, ſent me to aſk this Gentleman's Coachman where he drove you to, and ſwear if you be not found preſently, they'll Indict the Coachman for your Murther.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I wou'd you were all Hang'd for Company; why what a Plaguy Miſtake was here?—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! a lucky Hint —Bleſs me, Sir, I am under the greateſt Confuſion imaginable, can you forgive me, Sir? Upon my Honour, I thought I had been in my Inn; I aſk a thouſand Pardons, pray excuſe me to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Sir, never trouble your Head about the Lady.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Why Sir? I'm a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: A Gentleman Sir! And what then Sir?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: And am Maſter of an Eſtate to ſupport that Character Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Zounds, was ever Man ſo plagu'd, to have his Servants kick'd about like Foot-balls, his Houſe thunder'd about his Ears like a common Inn, then to be told impudently, I'm a Gentleman, and have an Eſtate to ſupport that Character?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I ask your pardon agen Sir, for the unlucky Accident, in miſtaking your Houſe, but cannot apprehend what Crime I have committed in my Apology.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Sir, without any manner of Apology, I wou'd be very proud to wait on you down Stairs.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: By no means, Sir—I muſt not permit that.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Death and the Devil, be gon without it, then.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: That I will Sir; but intreat the favour of ſeeing the Lady firſt; upon Honour I was never ſo concern'd in my Life: I wou'd not for Five hundred Pound quit the Houſe, till I have convinc'd her of my Error, and made my Acknowledgment upon my Knees.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Zounds, here's the Devil to do about her— Which way ſhall I get rid of him?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Pray Mrs. inform the Lady of my Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Hark yee Huſwife, ſtir out of this place, and I'll break your Neck down Stairs.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Why then I muſt be guilty of a ſecond Rudeneſs to acquit my ſelf of the firſt, I think that's the Room the Lady went into, Sir. Going towards the Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, Sir; where the Devil are you going—Zounds, advance one Step farther, and I'll indict you for a Robbery.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, ſince you are ſo poſitive, Sir, I will be gon; but pray Sir, is that Lady your Grand-daughter, Daughter, Neice, Couſin, or, or—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: 'Tis my Wife, my Wife, my Wife, my Wife Sir, do you hear that and tremble.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ods my Life, Sir, I beg your pardon with all my Heart and Soul—Your moſt Obedient, humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: The Devil go with you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To Lucy. My Maſter has not a Souſe of Money, elſe you wou'd not want your Fee. We were Robb'd coming down. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Zounds Sir, What do you loyter here for? Why don't you get after your Maſter. Go, troop. Turns him out.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you ſauntring here, get in to your Miſtreſs! What do's your Chops water at the ſight of a Man, ha?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p:
I'm ſure you are the worſt Sight I 〈◊〉 h •• ſeen 〈◊〉 ſent.
〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I don't underſtand this Miſtake tho'—He is a ſtrapping young Dog; I wiſh Laura had not ſeen him—— But I'll go ſee if he is gone, leſt there ſhou'd be more Reg ••• y at the •• ttom. Exit.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Enter on one ſide Faithful and Manage; on the other Conſtant and Clinch.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: FAithful, well met, I was going in ſearch of thee; my Affairs are ended, what Hopes of thine? Did the Project turn to thy Advantage?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: It gave me entrance to the Charming Fair, who receiv'd me with equal Tranſport; but juſt as ſhe conſented to come away with me, the old Fox return'd —A Curſe of his Diligence—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I came timely to my Maſter's Reſcue, Sir; and when his Pockets are repleniſh'd, I hope he'll own it.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: That I will, Manage.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: 'Tis now in my Power to lend thee Twenty Pieces, Friend —There they are— Gives Money.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I thankfully accept them; and next the finiſhing my own Wiſhes, I am pleas'd thou haſt gain'd thine; but after what Method to purſue mine, Heaven knows: I told Lucy I wou'd be about the Door in an Hour, but I know not if 'twill be in Laura's power to get out, or what can diſguiſe me, S • r David will certainly know me again, if he ſees me—The •• me is well nigh expir'd,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I have a Thought!—Cou'd you procure my Maſter a Red, or Blue Coat, in this Town, think you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I have my Regimental Surtout I rid down in, you know.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Right, that will do; I told him I ſerv'd an Officer; I warrant we'll paſs upon him—Come, ſtrip Clinch, ſtrips give me my Cloaths again— Strips and Champer with Clinch 〈◊〉
But 'tis neceſſary, Sir, that you change your 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: And what if you put a Patch croſs your Cheek, like a Scar?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: With all my Heart—I muſt, and will redeem her, or cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Nay, Twenty thouſand Pound gives an edge to Invention.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: So now I am in Statu qu • .

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Were ſhe not Miſtreſs of a Groat, I ſhou'd prefer her before the moſt celebrated Beauty in the Kingdom; our infant Years firſt ſowed the Seeds of Love, which as we grew, ripen'd to a perfect Paſſion; her Parents dying, left her to the Care of mine; oh in what Pleaſure have we paſt the Day, and quarrell'd with the Night that call'd us from each other. Whilſt I made the Campaign with you, Captain, my Father died! Oh fatal Thought, her Friends remov'd her to this Sir David Watchum's, 'tis twelve Months ſince, during which time, till now, I never cou'd find means to ſee or hear from her.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I know the Story perfectly well, and wiſh thou may'ſt ſucceed with all my Soul; but I find he is upon his Guard—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: If he cou'd ſummon Hell to guard her, I will by Policy or Force releaſe her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why then, pray reſolve upon which immediately; ſhall we lay open Siege or Blockade his Cittadel. The Head muſt always work before the Hands—Now 'tis neceſſary, e're we attempt, to know the weakeſt and ſtrongeſt Parrs; then we open our Trenches and Cannonade the Place, ruin their Ramparts, make a Breach, and then give the Aſſault, take the old Rogue by the Throat, plunder his Caſtle, and carry off the Booty— Which is the Lady, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Manage talks like a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ah, if we cou'd do that, Manage! I have good Intereſt in the Town—And they have notice of my Coming—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So much the better; the more Friends we have in the Garriſon, the ſooner we ſhall become Maſters of it —Well, as I am chief Engineer, and half the Artillery, I muſt ſurvey the Ground to find the moſt convenient Place to raiſe my Battery. But away, away, Sir, and diſguiſe your ſelf; the Drum beats— leave the reſt to Fortune, ſhe cannot always run againſt us— I have known the Sun riſe upon a private Centinel, who before his Setting was a Captain of Foot—Nothing like Diligence and Courage to nick the fickle Jade.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p:
Come, thou ſhalt be dreſs'd in a Moment Ex.
〈◊〉 .

div.head: SCENE, The Out-ſide • f Sir David's Houſe, Sir David in the Garden before his Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
I remember▪ Saving of a certain Phil • ſ •• her. 〈◊〉 thing is harder to keep than a Secret; but I think 'tis 〈…〉 harder to keep a handſome Woman—I am ſtrangely affected w • th this laſt Accident; and then the t'other Rogue that was here in the Morning, that ſerves an Officer—A pox on theſe Office •
〈◊〉 for they have more Stratagems in their Heads, than all the Kingdom beſides. But I have order'd the Smith to Barrica • e my Windows, from the Cellar to the 〈◊〉 , he'l •
〈…〉 but Laura muſt not ſee him 〈…〉 Girl, 〈…〉
•
ted at my Dog of a Co •• hman's Miſtake; I have invited h •• into the Garden, here the 〈…〉 M • i ••• nes.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
What favour • d • Davil,
〈◊〉 , h • s procur'd us this Liberty? It happens as I wou • d have it, if Faithful he but here now▪

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I'm am • n • d —For 'tis the faſt freſh open Air you have breath'd theſe twelve Months, Madam. But ſuppoſe Mr. Faithful ſhou'd be here! Yonder's the old Argus, he reſolves to watch you I ſee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay then!

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well Madam, How do you after your Fright? I ſent for you into the Garden, to take the Air—The Air is g •• d after a Fright —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Ay, if one cou'd change the Place too, Sir David, but the Air of my Chamber and this is much the ſame—But let 〈◊〉 where I will, if you are there, I find no Difference in the Air— I know not what ails me, but when I ſee you▪ I 〈…〉 draw Breath.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ha! ſhe loves me▪ Oh happy 〈◊〉 — —Ir •••• , Madam! And are thoſe Sighs pleaſant or painful, pray?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh very painful, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Then you muſt have a Huſband to care thoſe Sighs. Child.

div.stage: Faithful and Manage appear between the Scenes.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: She's here! Oh the charming Maid—but that old Monſter is with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What think you of a married Life, L •• ra ▪

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Of nothing better—I might diſſemble like many of my Sex; exclaim againſt Marriage and Mankind; profeſs to dye in a Cloyſter, or a Maid at large—Maſk my real Inclinations, fain Indifference to Love, and place all my Happineſs in my own Sex—But I have a Heart too ſincere; and therefore frankly own, that the utmoſt of my Ambition is to be a Wife.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: To me ſhe means—Oh how ſhall I deliver her!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Madam; why ſhou'd a Lady loſe the prime of her youth, when ſhe may do ſo much good in her Generation; I reſolve to follow your Example to a hair.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Good Wits jump—I reſolve to marry too; I have every day freſh Offers, very advantagious Offers, but my Heart is prepoſſeſs'd, dear Laura, for I will own it now, I love you exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So, now 'tis out.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: More, if poſſible, than you love me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: That's very poſſible, truly.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Love her! Oh the rank old Goat; Death! that Confeſſion has made me looſe all Patience.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, pray be content a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Come, don't bluſh, Laura; thy Sighs betray'd thy Love, but I'm diſcreet.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Now do I long to tell him he lies in his Throat.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Egad, Sir, you had better loſe your longing at this time.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What do you ſay, Sir—that I love you! your Opinion is ſmall proof of your Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why ſo, Child?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Becauſe you never was more miſtaken in your Life; for inſtead of loving you, I hate you mortally.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Oh bleſſed Sound!

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Really! but why ſo, prithee?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay, you love without Reaſon; and perhaps I hate by the ſame Rule.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if her declaration be not ſo kind as you wou'd have it, it▪ is not the leſs ſincere.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Is it not, Gilflirt, after what I have done for her?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Yes, you have done for me, I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, pray be not angry, but ſtate the Caſe right.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: If Love has render'd me charming in your Eyes, conſider how he has drawn you in mine.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: She's amiable, you ugly——She's gay, you moroſe— She's Generous—you a Miſer—She's ſixteen—You ſixty—She has the fineſt Teeth in the World——You but one in your Head, and that ſhakes, and the firſt Fit of Coughing, good by to it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A Deviliſh Wench——She has drawn him to a Hair.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Mark Lucy's Deſcription, and then tell me if theſe be not irreſiſtible Charms, for one of my Age and Conſtitution.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What Woman do you think, Sir, on this ſide fourſcore, wou'd have ſuch a Bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: She ſhall, Miſtreſs, or ſhe ſhall have no body, mark that; and your Witticiſms, Mrs. Frippery, ſhall get you nothing— How now! who do you want?Faithful and Manage come forward.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: My dear Faithful! I know him in all Diſguiſes; how ſhall I forbear running into his Arms?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Have a care, Madam, if you diſcover you know him, you'll never ſee him more; Manage has ſome Plot in his Head, by his winking.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What is it you look at, Sir! why don't you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Be calm, Sir, and take no notice of the Lady.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I was ſo charm'd with the fineneſs of the Proſpect in that Moment you ſpoke, Sir, I was not maſter of my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: And now you are Maſter of it, Sir, what have you to ſay?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir; only having the misfortune to break my Chariot—I took a walk this way, till it is put in order again; and coming by this Houſe, my Man told me that you entertain'd ſome hard thoughts of him, from ſome diſcourſe that paſs'd between you to day—So I preſum'd to call, to clear his Reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: This is the Officer! A Rogue in red now; and the Simple-hunter with him—I don't like 'em—As for that, Sir, you need not give your ſelf any farther trouble, for I have nothing to do with his Reputation, nor yours neither.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I hope 'tis no offence to look about me a little; this Houſe is finely ſituated—'Tis the beſt Air I have breath'd this Twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Pox o' your Compliment—That's your Miſtake, Sir; 'tis the worſt Air in the Univerſe—Let me adviſe you to get out of it as faſt as you can; for 'tis very fatal to Strangers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He tells you truth, Sir; for ever ſince I breath'd this Air, I have neither eat, drank, or ſlept with Eaſe.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
I am ſorry for that, Madam; but I find a quite contrary
effect; methinks I feel new Life, and I have a ſtrong hope to carry off the Health I wiſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I wiſh, Sir, your Legs wou'd be pleas'd to carry off your Body.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, I will not be troubleſome—but I deſire you wou'd give me leave to take a view of your Gardens; I have bought me a ſmall Seat in a Country Village, and I deſign to have a pretty Garden made.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ah! wou'd you were buried in the Garden—go, get in, Gentlewoman, go—he has no buſineſs with you, you don't belong to the Garden.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To Lucy. Find ſome way to bring your Lady down again; do you hear? and let her pretend— Whiſpers to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I hear; but how to put it in practice, I know not.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I am diſtracted! Oh Invention! where art thou? help me Brains, or ceaſe to think.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you loiter for, ha? get in—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir David, you uſe us like Slaves; ſend us in and out at pleaſure—Is my Lady a Perſon to be treated ſo by her Guardian? Theſe twelve Months we have not ſeen the ſhadow of any Hat but yours—I'm ſure nothing that's Male has reach'd our Eyes.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why how now, Mrs. Prate-apace; if you don't like your living, troop off. Go—There are more Servants to be had.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I ſhall certainly diſcover my ſelf, if he goes on at this Rate—Sir, I had rather quit this place immediately, than you ſhou'd incommode the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Pray Sir David, mind your own Servants, you ſhall never have any power over mine. Sir, let me adviſe you to tarry till to morrow; 'tis dangerous travelling too late; let me intreat you ſtay in this Town till to morrow—What ſaid Manage to you Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ay, pray take my Lady's advice, Sir. You ſhall know within; take Courage, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Zounds, get in, I believe you want to lie with him all Night, you are ſo concern'd for his ſtay.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I hope ſome brave Man will attempt the reſcue of my Miſtreſs. He puſhes 'em in.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: My Heart ſwells at theſe Indignities, and I cou'd ſhake his deteſted rotten Soul, out of its wither'd ſapleſs Carcaſs.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Be eaſie, Sir, Paſſion will do us no good—I have ſomething in my Head may hit, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Sir, I ſhou'd be the cauſe of your being angry with your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: My Daughter!

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I aſk your Pardon, Sir, may be 'tis your Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: She ſhall be e'er long, Sir.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.l: You ſhall be Worms meat firſt. Aſide.
I had better knock him down, and fetch her out this moment.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And the next moment fetches you to Goal. Indeed, Sir, you had better keep your temper:—You have made a very excellent Choice, Sir, wou'd all Huſt 〈◊〉 m • nage their Wi • es ſo, 〈◊〉 ſhou'd not have ſo many C •• quers bread.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I don't deſign my Wife ſhall follow the way of the World.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Second him, Sir, keep him in talk a l • ttle—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: You do well, Sir, 'tis below a Man to let his Wife rule, and rattle where ſhe pleaſes; to viſit, and be viſited by half the Fops; in the Nation; for my part, had I a Wife, I ſhou'd follow your Method.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: 'Egad, I believe I was miſtaken in this Gentleman. I wiſh, Sir, I had this Lecture read to ſome that blame me for my Conduct.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Sir, I'll go into your Houſe, and write it down this moment; it ſhan't coſt you a Farthing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I'll not give you the trouble, Sir, I ſhall remember 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! undone, undone; help, help; oh Sir David! what have you brought upon us?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What the Devil do you bawl ſo for?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! the ſaddeſt Accident has befallen my poor Lady!—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! her Lady, ſaid She?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Peace, Sir, and mind the Plot— Aſide to Faithful.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What accident, ha? You roar as ſhe had broke a Leg, or an Arm.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Worſe, Sir, worſe, much worſe; She's mad, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Mad!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Ay, Diſtracted, Sir—When you thruſt us in, ſhe found the Smith barricading her Windows; aſſoon as ever ſhe l • id her Eyes upon the Ir • n • ars; her looks grow wild, her 〈…〉
Starts and broken Speeches, convince me of her Brain being turn'd —When before I was aware—She catch'd up an Iron Bar, and broke the Blackſmith's Pate; She beat her head againſt the Wall—runs, skips, ſings, dances, ſtamps, raves, and throws all the things about the Room—I wou'd have ſhut her in, but ſhe ſet up ſuch a Roar, that I left the Door open, and fled for my Life.—Make the beſt of your Plot, Manage— Aſide.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Mercy on us! what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Here ſhe comes, oh my poor Lady!—with your great Baſe Viol in her hand; oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! if ſhe breaks my Baſe, I had rather loſe five Pounds: Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have Patience, Sir, I may be ſerviceable to you in this Affair, as little Opinion as you had of my ſkill to day.

div.stage: Enter Laura, with a Baſe and Papers; her Cloaths aukwardly hanging.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Give me Liberty and Love,
Give me Love and Liberty,
From an Iron Grate,
And the Man I hate,
Dear Fortune ſet me free.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: What deſign you by this, Manage?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To put you in poſſeſſion of your Miſtreſs, before I have done, Sir, if you'll be quiet.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What, are you a Blackſmith? To Sir David.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh pox o' the Blackſmith, how ſhe harps upon him!—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Ho! now I know you, you are a Singing-maſter.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: A Singing-maſter! good lack, good lack—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Here is a piece of Muſick, which I have juſt now receiv'd from London; 'tis part of the laſt new Opera—there, there, there's a Part for you. gives Sir David a Paper. Ha! are not you the new Eunuch? Ay, 'tis he! here, here, here's your part.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: A Letter, Oh! for an opportunity to read it. draws off by degrees.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Give me Liberty and Love.

Give me Love and Liberty— Come, why don't you ſing.
To Sir David. She beats time all this while, with her hand upon his head, and with her foot upon his toes.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Poor Laura, I can't ſing, Child—Zounds, Death and the Devil, ſhe has kill'd my Toe.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What, won't you ſing, I'll break the Fiddle then.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Pray, Sir David, humour her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Let me adviſe you comply with her, Sir; ſhe's poſſeſs'd, and with a very miſchievous Daemon.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Come, begin. Give me Liberty and Love.

p.stage: They all ſing whilſt Faithful reads.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
Reads
Dear Faithful, find ſome way to deliver me, or what I now act in jeſt, will follow in earnest; I have all my Jewels and Writings about me; for I have broke the old Man's Cloſet for them, and I'll find a way to get money preſently. Yours entirely,
Laura.
Yes, I will deliver thee, or dye for it. Manage, read that.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Recommend me for a white Witch to Sir David; let me alone for the reſt.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Poor Lady! I am extremely concern'd for her, Sir; pray conſult my Servant about her Diſtemper; in my Opinion ſhe's bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I doubt ſo too, Sir; has he really ſkill in theſe matters?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: No Man in the Kingdom more, I aſſure you, he has cur'd ſeveral to my Knowledge, both in Spain and Flanders.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why do you look at me ſo? Did you never ſee an old Woman before? I'd have you to know, Miſtreſs, I have been as handſome as you—but Age alters every body—I have been the Mother of ſixteen Children—all Boys——Heark ye, let me council you—don't marry an old Fellow.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, why ſo pray?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Becauſe your Youth will renew his Age—and you'll be plagu'd with him to eternity—I married an old fuſty Guardian, becauſe I cou'd not get out of his hands; which is the reaſon why you ſee ſo many Wrinkles in my Face, ha, ha, ha. In my conſcience there he ſtands—What, can I go no where, but you muſt follow me—ye old cripling Cuckold you—Look ye how angry he is now at being call'd Cuckold——Yet he wou'd marry a young Wife— —ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Mercy upon us! how does ſuch things come in her head?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: The Wildneſs of her Fancy—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I'll do your buſineſs for you, Sir; I have conſulted the Stars, and find ſhe is bewitch'd by an old Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: By an old Woman! Ay indeed ſhe talks of an old Woman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It is a very troubleſome Spirit that is in her, and muſt be charm'd out into another, or ſhe can't be cur'd —Tell me, Sir, can you procure any body for that purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Here's her Maid, won't ſhe do?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What! Do you think I'd have the Devil put into me, Sir, I aſk you pardon for that.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Heark! There's my Drum beating up for Volunteers— What ſay you my Lads, are you for the Wars? Her Majeſty has honour'd me with a Collonel's Commiſſion; I'm juſt now raiſing my Regiment—you ſhall all ſerve under me. Come—hold, now I think on't, I want a hundred Guineas to raiſe Men with—Heark ye, won't you lend me a hundred Guineas? To Sir David.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Lack a day, it makes me weep, to ſee how many ſorts of Madneſſes poſſeſs her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A good thought for ſome Money—Humour her, Sir, whatever ſhe aſks for, let her have.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Lend me a hundred Guineas, I ſay, or my Soldiers ſhall batter your Houſe about your Ears.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: For Heavens ſake, Sir, give 'em her, you'll have them again ſafe.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I wou'd adviſe you to let her have 'em, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, be ſure you take care of them; there, there is threeſcore in that Purſe, you may tell her there is a hundred; but take care I have them again. to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, when we have nothing elſe to do with 'em. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Give it me—ſo, now my Boys will you ſerve the Queen?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart, under you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: There then, there's Gold for you, Sirrah; gives him a Guinea. and what ſay you, you are a handſome proper Fellow, ſix foot high —I'll make you Serjeant of the Grenadiers—What ſay you, will you ſerve under me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Humph! He wou'd rather ſerve her another way, I dare ſwear. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
And know no Joy beyond it; ſerve ye!—by Heaven,
that I will, with my Life, 〈…〉 through all Difficulties and Danger; and die by your ſide, or 〈◊〉 you off ſafe.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Then there's M • ney, my 〈◊〉 to 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Hold, hold, Laura, you muſt 〈…〉
•
ney; Lu • y take care 〈◊〉 . I hope, Sir, you'll 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I'll ſee to that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Return the Money, to whom? They are my Soldiers, 〈◊〉 the Money mine—I borrow'd it of the moſt confounded old Rogue in Peterborough; tell him I ſay ſo ——but you look 〈◊〉 an honeſt Man, I'll mak • your 〈◊〉 : — 〈…〉 you exerciſe, Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Lord, oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Serjeant t • ke heed; to the right and left by half 〈…〉 form Files upon the Flanks of the Battalion—March—ha, ha, you are curſed dull, Serjeant —

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am a little aukward at firſt, Collonel, but I ſhall learn.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh! Sta ••• .

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll teach you then— Silence, Join your right hand to your Firelock — Cock your Firelock— — Preſent; Fire—Excellent.
sp.l: Give me Liberty and Love,
Give me Love and Liberty. Sing • .

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh ſad, oh ſad! what ſhall I do? Pray Sir deſire y •• r Man to try his ſkill,

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Manage, the Gentleman implores your Aid.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
I am ready, if he can find any body to make the F •••••
ment; it muſt be a Man, Sir—will you endure it your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: No, faith and troth not I!

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, Sir, to do you and the Lady ſervice. I'll venture — —but take care, Manage, that you bring the Devil out of 〈◊〉 again — —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, that I can eaſily; for he is not half ſo hard to get out of a Man, as he is out of a Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Good lack! what ſhou'd the reaſon of th • t be, I •••
der! Aſide. Sir, I thank you heartily — a very •••
thy Gentleman thi • ,— —Well, what 〈…〉 , Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Stand ſtill, I charge you—And do you fetch us an eaſie Chair, Miſtreſs.— to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Ex.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Stay, I muſt limit your bounds; there Sir, you muſt not for your Life croſs this Circle.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I ſhall obſerve you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very well; Pray, Madam, be pleas'd to fit down.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Sit down! why is Dinner coming?—Ho, cry a Mercy! you are a Barber; hold, hold, you ſhall ſhave my Corporal firſt, to try your Razor.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Lord, oh Lord! what ſhall I ſay to her?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Keep your place, Sir——No, no, Sir, I am a Shoe-maker, and if I fit your Foot, and pleaſe you, I deſire your Honour wou'd let me have the buſineſs of your Regiment.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then pray ſit down, Sir, that I may take meaſure. She ſits down. Now for you, Sir, you muſt kneel right before her— cloſer—cloſer yet; there, look full in her Eyes—Claſp both her Hands in yours. Manage pulls a Book out of his pocket, and looks on't.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Give me Liberty and Love,
Give me Love and Liberty. Sings

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: My Charming Angel, Oh let me kneel here for ever, for ever gaze on thoſe dear Eyes; how I have languiſh'd for thee, Heaven only knows.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And what I have born for thee, Hell cannot match; Oh, if Manage fail in his Plot, I'm undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Fear not, my Love, he is lucky at Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What are they doing?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Alpha, Beta, Gama, Delta.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Bleſs me, what are thoſe the Names of the Spirits?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Philo ſe en paſias, gloſſais, kai en to panti poto, kai en to panti topo—Now do you be well, Madam; and do you ſeem to be Mad, Sir, quick, quick—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why what a many Devils there are! certainly ſhe has a Legion in her.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Where am I, Lucy? Methinks I wake from ſome untoward Dream.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: She recovers, Sir. How do you, 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I'm glad on't. How doſt thou do, 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Pretty well.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Death, Sir, keep your Place, or you'll • poil 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! my Brain-pan ſplits—I'm all • fam • , my 〈◊〉 boils o'er, give me room, I'll ſcale the Region of the 〈◊〉 , and 〈◊〉 the Winds down headlong on us all.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, he's ſtark Mad; What ſhall we do 〈◊〉 him now?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We ſhall do well enough with him; but keep your Pl ••• for he's very Deſperate.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Defend me Heaven, what ails the Gentlem ••
▪

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: He'll kill us all; the Man's bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Here, here, Ladies ſtand in this Circle, and don't 〈◊〉 it for your Lives. Sets 'em in a 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh pray Sir, read again—

sp.speaker: Faith,
sp.p: What's here, old Belzebub! No, 'tis his S ••• h 〈◊〉 Cracker; I'll ſet fire to it and blow it up—Ho, lo, where 〈◊〉 you Scoundrels, Dogs, Rogues, Cooks, the Devil wants his Dinner, and you muſt ſpit this Swine, Hell dines on Hog's Fleſh to Day. Draws his Sword.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Undone, undone; the Spirit grows too ſtrong for • y Art! fly, fly, Sir, for Life—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, ſave me, ſave me. Runs in and ſlaps the Door.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Now, now, make your Eſcape; he has ſlap'd the Door after him—Quick▪ quick—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: My Life, my Soul!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: My Angel, my All. End race.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! Don't ſtand Lifeing and Dearing now, but make haſte to Mr. Truſty's, I'll bring the Parſon after you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ay, good Madam, be quick.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Any where, good Manage.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Fly Manage, and bring Lovely with thee too, to be Witneſs of my good Fortune, this Hour makes thee mine for ever:
sp.l: Now in thy Arms immortal Joys I'll taſte,
And quite forget our anxious Sorrows paſt.

p.hi: Now Heav'n be prais'd, we've Liberty at laſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Oh, I'm Robb'd, Raviſh'd, Dead and Buried—My Cloſet is broke open, and all my Writings gone; Mr. Conjurer,
Mr. Conjurer, can you help me to the Thief? Ha! no Body to be ſeen! Bleſs me—Lucy—Laura, why Laura? Ah Murder, Murder, Thieves, Thieves. Crys out till he comes down.

Here, where are all my Servants? Enter Servants. Run ſome one way, ſome another; make enquiry thro' the whole Town for Mrs. Laura; ſhe is carry'd away by two Rogues or Devils, I know not which, run, run—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why if the Devil has carry'd her away, Sir, where can we run?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: To Hell, ye Dog, do you ſtand to prate?—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Marry look her there your ſelf an you will— Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh that I ſhou'd believe theſe Conjuring, Soldiering Raſcals; but I'll find 'em, if they are above ground; and if they are mortal, I'll hang 'em, that's my Comfort. Exit.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE, The Street before Mr, Truſty's Door; Roger comes out of the Houſe with a Pitch-fork on his Shoulder, and a Lantern in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
IT will be very dark e'er I get home—Od, I'm main Merry, Maſter Truſty keeps rare Nappy Ale, and Dick the Butler is an honeſt Fellow; Lord, Sirs, how bravely theſe Gentlefolk live—Methinks I like it hugely; and I'm perſuaded, I was deſign'd for a Gentleman, but was ſpoil'd in the making; nay, nay, I was made well enough too, that's the Truth on't; but 'tis that Damn'd Jade Fortune that has ſpoil'd me; for an I had an Eſtate now, I know how to live like a Gentleman—I cou'd ſcorn the Poor, and ſcrew up my Tenants, and wou'd ſooner give Ten Pound to a Wench, than Two Pence for Charity; I cou'd quickly turn—My Cart into a Coach, and my Man Plod into a Coachman—I cou'd hurry into the Tradeſmen's Books— Wear fine Cloaths, and never pay for them —Lie with their Wives, and make my Footmen beat their Huſbands, when they come to aſk me for Money. Get drunk with Lords, and break the
Watchmen's Heads—Scour the Streets, and ſleep in a Bawdy-houſe—Sell my Lands, and pay no Debts—Get a Charge of Baſtards for the Pariſh to maintain—Then, by the help of a Commiſſion, Tranſport my ſelf out of their Reach—

div.stage: Enter Sir Jeffry Conſtant, in Riding Habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Do you hear, Friend?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Mehap I do—And mehap I do not; What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Nay, the Matter's not great—Do you live at that Houſe?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I did a little while ago——When I was in the Cellar.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: A Comical Fellow. Then you don't ſerve Mr. Truſty?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No, Sir, I ſerve his Maſter, tho' as moſt Farmers do their Landlords.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I underſtand you: You Rent one of the Knight's Farms?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ay, and a Plaguy Dear one too——

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Say you ſo! That's pity; I'll ſpeak a good Word for thee——Is Mr. Trusty at home?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I thank you heartily. Yes, Sir, he's at home. Runs to the Door and knocks. Truſty opens the Door and ſhrieks out, and throws it to again. Wookers, what's the Matter now?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Was not that Mr. Truſty?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Within. Oh undone, undone; Clinch peeps out as affrighted. here's my old Maſter.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, I heard a Noiſe, but can't tell what they ſaid—— But on you pleaſe to come wo' me, Sir, I'll carry you in the Back-way.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: The Back-way——What can be the meaning of this? Why ſhou'd he ſtart at ſight of me? There muſt be ſomething more in it than I can fathom; and yet I think he's an honeſt Man. I never found any thing to the contrary. Prithee, Friend, knock again. Roger knocks, then liſtens.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: They are all aſleep, Sir—For I cannot ſo much as hear a Mouſe ſtir——

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Aſleep! That's impoſſible——But come, Friend, ſhew me the Back-door you ſpoke of——

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Ay, Sir: But upon ſecond Thoughts,——I muſt be a little wary too. Are not you ſome Rogue, that comes to rob the Houſe
with half a dozen Piſtols about you? For look yee, I'm an honeſt Man, and won't be drawn in for a Halter.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: You Raſcal, Do I look like a Thief?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, nay, as for Looks—That's no matter, de yee ſee —I have known many a Rogue with as good a Countenance— No Diſparagement to your's, I promiſe you. So that I ſhall not ſtir one ſtep without you'll ſtand ſearch—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I ſhall break your Head, Sirrah, if you provoke me, I tell you but that.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And what muſt I be doing on the mean time,—Ha! old Gentleman?—Break my Head, quotha!—You are miſtaken— —We don't uſe to take broken heads in our Country, mun—Ha, ha, I won't ſhew you the Back-door now, and how will you help your ſelf?—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I know all the Doors of this Houſe as well as you— And can ſhew my ſelf in— Going.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Can you ſo—But I'll watch you—I wonder who this old Fellow is.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Sure ſome Madneſs has ſeiz'd the Family; for certainly I'm not chang'd—Without Diſpute, Truſty knows me; but I'll find the Cauſe preſently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And ſo will I— Exit.

div.stage: Enter out of the Houſe Captain Conſtant, Lovely and Clinch.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: So, Sir, here's Muſick to your Wedding, with a Witneſs. What do you intend to do now?—Do you think it poſſible to perſuade your Father too, that he died of an Apoplexy?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I fear, Clinch, that's beyond the Art of thy Impudence to do—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, this Plot was none of my Impudence's contriving, that's my Comfort—I'm but a Servant; my Maſter told me, he was in Mourning for his Father—And faith I reſolve not to believe the Father to the contrary. Such an entire Deference have I for all your Commands, Sir.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Why thou can'ſt not ſure have the Confidence to ſtand it out to his Face.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Never fear me, Sir—You don't know what I can do —What ſay you, Sir? Shall we perſuade the old Gentleman into a Ghoſt; or will you own your Fault, and refund the Money?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Neither, Clinch—I have more Duty, than to attempt the 〈◊〉 ; and more Neceſſity, than to ſubmit to the other—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, if you be ſo divided—What do you propoſe?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I know not what to do—I'm glad the Ceremony was over, before he came.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And the Money ſent away—What think you of my Houſe, till the Heat of the Diſcovery be over? 'Tis my Opinion your Preſence won't be proper—I warrant Sir David will be in purſuit of Mrs. Laura preſently too—But we have ſeen her fairly Marry'd; ſo that Faithful is out of Danger; we'll leave him here —

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Shall I not take Belinda with us? I fear as much for her, as for my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: So there's no Body fears for me, I find— Aſide.
I am like to have my Part truly.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, truſt to her Management—She turn'd the Act upon her Father, you know, and made him impoſe her own Choice upon her. Let Clinch ſtay and uſe his own Diſcretion—If he can banter Sir Jeffry, and ſave his Bones, let him: But be ſure to give us notice of all that paſſes.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What if my Bones are broke?—I thank you heartily for your Love, Sir.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: No, no, Clinch; take heed you keep out of the reach of his Cane.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Or he'll make me feel; he's Fleſh and Blood—Heark, I hear him coming, Good bye to you, Sir— Runs in.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis time for us to fly— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Well, I'm glad my Lady's Marry'd; for if this old Spark had come three Hours ſooner, I wou'd not have ventur'd Two to Ten of the Match—I can't imagine where the Bridegroom's gone—Nor what he will do, when my Maſter comes to have a right Underſtanding; but I reſolve to keep him ignorant as long as I can. Ho, here he comes.

Oh, Sir, I am frighted out of my Wits; I went to ſerve my Lady's Italian Greyhound, and I found a great ſwinging Dog, as large as an Ox, with two great Eyes, as big as Buſhels; and before I cou'd call out,—Whip it was vaniſh'd—

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p:
Mercy upon us —'Twas certainly Sir Jeffry,— Clinch.
Enter Clinch.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Sir, did you call—

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Did not you ſay your old Maſter appear'd in the Shape of a Dog?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: In a huge great Dog?

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: As big as an Ox.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, as big as an Elephant.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Ah! then it was certainly him I ſaw. Oh dear, oh dear, if the Houſe be haunted, I muſt leave it. I cannot live in't, if I might have a Thouſand Pounds; and may be, he'll appear to no Body but me—I am ſure I never did him any harm; 'tis true, I did not love him, becauſe he was ſomething Stingey—— He never gave me a Farthing in his Life—

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Nay, for that matter, I have got many a fair Pound by him, and yet he appear'd to me to Day.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir. In what Shape, pray?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Like an Ox, or an Elephant.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: No, in his own Shape; but I wiſh I may never ſee him more, for I was horribly fear'd.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What had he a Cloven Foot, Sir, did you mind?

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Nay, for my part,— I know not whether he had any Feet or no,—Ha! bleſs me, defend me,—Protect me— Avoid, Satan— Retreating all this while. I never wrong'd that Form, which thou haſt ta'en; ſo tell him—And for my Money, I have accounted for that; and all Things are rectify'd— Exit.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Oh! ſhield me ye Stars. runs in.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: O Legs! ſave me, ſave me. runs in.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What? Am I become a Monſter! Do I affright all I come near? What can be the Reaſon of this? The Doors are all Barricaded; and when I knock, none will anſwer—Prithee, Friend, aſk ſome Body the Cauſe of theſe Diſorders?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No! Sir, I'll not budge a Foot; for I dan't know what to ſay to you. The Family were all well, and in their right Senſes, when I left them; and now upon Sight of you, they are all diſtracted, I think—I wiſh you be'n't a Conjurer, or heark ye, Sir,—Is not your Name Emmes—Rais'd by the French Prophets to Life again?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Sirrah, I believe you are the Devil: This Fellow will make me Mad. This muſt be ſome Stratagem to abuſe me; and this Rogue is in their Intereſt. Why don't you go about your Buſineſs, Sirrah? What do you hanker after me for?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Nay—an you go to that, what do you lounge about
this Houſe for?—Oh! Dolly, are you there; here's an old Gentleman is quite out of Patience.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Trembling above. Oh, oh, oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Hey day! What have you got the Palſy?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What ails you to tremble ſo, Sweetheart? Is Mr. Truſty within?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: I, I, I, I, I, o, o, o, o, Roger—Ha, ha, have a care, ca, care—Don't yo, yo, you come near him—Nor let him to, to, to, touch you, even with his Little Finger—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Bleſs me! What ails the Wench?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No, why what's the Matter? He has not the Plague about him, has he? Or is he a Spy from the King of France—Od an he be, I'll maul him—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Oh, oh,——'tis a, a, Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: The Devil it is— Takes his Pitchfork off his Shoulder, and holds it out at Sir Jeffry.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: A Ghoſt, where?—Who—What's a Ghoſt? Death, what means ſhe?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Od's fleſh, my Hair ſtands an end. Look ye—Keep off Mr. Belzebub, or—or—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Look ye, Sweetheart, what Frenzy has poſſeſs'd you, I know not—But if you take me for a Ghoſt—You are deceiv'd. Therefore look well at me —Do I not appear like Fleſh and Blood?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Ay, bo, bo, bo, but we, we, we know yo, yo, you a, a, a, a, are not ſo, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Zounds, will they perſuade me out of my Life? See, Friend,—Do I walk like a Spirit? Do's the Dead move, and talk as I do?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: When I am Dead,—If you aſk me, I'll reſolve you, if I can.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Why? Feel me, feel me—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Feel the Devil—Mercy upon me—Keep off, I ſay— Will ye—Or I'll ſtick your Ghoſtſhip thro' the Guts——

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What ſhall I do—Nay, prithee, Friend.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Friend me no Friends—Look ye, I am not to be coax'd by the Devil, when I know 'tis the Devil. Indeed when you are got into a Lawyer, or a handſome Woman, one may be trapan'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Why will you be ſo poſitive? Has any Body impos'd upon you?—Pray who told you I was dead?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Thoſe that knew very well, Sir
But I am not able to bear the fight of you any longer—Now let Clinch take his Part.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Go to be Hang'd—Hell and Furies!—Ha, what do I ſee—My Son's Man! Sirrah, Sirrah, what makes you here?—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Mercy upon me—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What do you ſtare at, Raſcal, ha?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: But that I believe you are dead, Sir, or I ſhou'd ſwear you are alive—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: You believe I am dead, Rogue,—How dare you believe ſuch an impud ••• Lye?—Where's the Rake your Maſter? I find now who has rais'd this Report. Sirrah, what's your Buſineſs here?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: To wait on my Maſter, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: To wait on your Maſter——And where is your Maſter, pray?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, for my part, Sir, I am not qualify'd to anſwer a Spirit—There's Mr. Anthem, the Afternoon Lecturer, within. He has juſt Marry'd Mr. Faithful to a great Heireſs which he brought in juſt now—Roger here may ſtep and call him out a little.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: With all my Heart—If there be any thing that troubles his Mind, I'll go this Minute—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Sirrah—I'll qualify you for an Hoſpital—I will ye Dog— Runs after him.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Well run, Clinch; Well run, Ghoſt!—Ad 'tis a Plaguy Malitious Spirit tho'.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh. Runs in.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I'll venture to ſpeak to it once more—— In the Name of Goodneſs—What is it that diſturbs your Reſt? Pray tell me; and as I'm an honeſt Man, I'll do you Juſtice as far as Twenty Pounds a Year Free-Land, and all the Crops of my Fa •• goes—For I perceive you was my Landlord, whilſt you was Living; and tho' your Son ſeems to be a very honeſt Gentleman, yet I don't know what he may prove for a Landlord—Then pray ſpeak, can I ſerve you?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to be angry—I muſt ſeem to comply with this Fellow—Yes, Friend, it is in thy power to ſerve me; if thou can'ſt procure me the ſight of Mr. Truſty, 'tis with him my 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I'll do my beſt Endeavours, Sir—but keep your diſtance— He goes a little way, then turns back. But heark ye, Sir, ſuppoſe he won't come out, can't I tell him your Mind?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: No, no; I muſt ſpeak with him my ſelf—Death!—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Good lack—what, perhaps—your Soul won't reſt elſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Heaven give me Patience!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Going, turns back. But after you have ſpoken with him, will you be quiet, and haunt this Houſe no more? That's the Queſtion, look ye!

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: A Pox of thy impertinent Interrogations; no—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: That's enough!—but hold, muſt he come out, or ſpeak to you through the Window?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Any way, ſo I do but ſpeak to him—Oh, oh!—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Very well, very well. Going. But heark ye, Sir Ghoſt —you'll be here—or Mr. Truſty will be woundy angry with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Oh Patience, Patience! or I ſhall burſt. Aſide. Ay, ay, I'll not ſtir.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Well, I'll take your word. Going. Hold, hold, one thing more, and I ha' done—Pray tell me the Nature of a Ghoſt— do you troubled Spirits fly in the Air, or ſwim in the Water, pray?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Oh! the Devil—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Mercy upon us! what, are you with the Devil, ſay you; Oh Heaven help you! Well then, are you ſure he will ſee you? for every body can't ſee a Ghoſt, they ſay, eſpecially if the Devil be in't.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Zounds, I tell you, he'll ſee me as plain as you ſee me.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, nay, that's plain enough—Well, I'll knock, but, but, but don't you come an Inch nearer me, I charge you Knocks.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Wou'd I had been a hundred Miles off, when I firſt ſaw thee. What has my graceleſs Son been doing!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Who's there?Speaks within.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Dolly, prithee tell Maſter Truſty that he muſt ſpeak to this Ghoſt, or there's nothing to be done—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: I doubt he will not be perſuaded to it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why, let him ſpeak to it through the Window, or from the top of the Houſe—ſo he does but ſpeak to it; but in ſhort, it muſt be ſpoke to, and by him, for it is a confounded ſullen Spirit, and will tell its mind to no body elſe—He ſmells curſedly of Brimſtone—Look ye, if Maſter will come out, it ſhan't hurt him— for I'll keep it off with my Fork, ſo tell him, Dolly.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: I'll inform him.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: So, I have done it you ſee—Here's Maſter Truſty.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I thank you. Going towards the Window.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: I am not able to ſtand, if it comes near me—Why are you thus diſturb'd, Sir Jeffrey?—I aſſure you, your Son has done every thing very juſtly.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Why are you thus impos'd upon, Mr. Truſty, to believe I am dead?—My Son, quotha!—Oh that I had never got that Son— Weeps.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: I know not what to think; ſure 'tis no Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Well, this thing is the likeſt Fleſh and Blood, that ever I ſaw—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Pray do but touch me, Mr. Truſty,—'tis very odd, you will not be perſuaded to touch me. Puts out his hand towards the Window.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Take heed, Mr. Truſty.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd I fear, I never wrong'd him—I'll venture; but firſt— Holds up his hand as if he prayed now—ha! 'tis a real Hand,—He's living;—Sir, I am convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Say you ſo—why then if you are alive, the Fright's over, and I'm glad on't with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: I aſk your pardon, Sir; I have been abus'd—groſly abus'd; Sir Jeffrey your Son came down in Mourning, and aſſur'd me you was dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I'll make him mourn for ſomething, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Ah! that he does already, Sir, for I have paid him all the Rents in my hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Have you ſo?—'Tis the laſt Rents he ſhall ever take for any Land of mine—I'll diſinherit him this Day.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Oh! undone, undone for ever—Oh, oh, oh!Weeps.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Here's ſmall Mirth towards, as far as I can find. I'll e'en take t'other Horn of Ale, and t'other Buſs of Dolly— Ex. into the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What has that Rogue's Extravagance coſt me? But if he ſtarves for the future, I care not; he never ſhall get a Groat from me.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, then we may all go for Soldiers. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh! I know not; but wherever he is —I am wretched, he has made me miſerable, I'm ſure. Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: No, Mr. Truſty; though you have us'd me dirtily, in making me the Jeſt of your Family; for you might have diſcover'd the Impoſture with leſs precaution; yet I'll not take that advantage which the Laws allow. You have ſerv'd me long, and I believe you honeſt. I'll diſcharge you from what you have paid my undutiful Child—Let him take what he has got, and make the beſt on't.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: That's ſomething however. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: You are generous, Sir Jeffry, even beyond my hopes: But Oh! there is yet a greater offence behind, which cuts me deeper than the Money—Alas! my Daughter—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Is married to your Son; Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Then he is compleatly wretched—A Wife, and no Eſtate; ha, ha, ha; I'm glad on't with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: There's a kind Father now —I muſt give my Maſter notice of his good Fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Oh! ſay not ſo, Sir; be not glad of my Child's Ruin; had I known you liv'd, the Match had never been.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Go; You are not the Man I took you for—you are but a Knave. You ought to have been as juſt to my Heir, as to my ſelf—What, was your Blood fit to be popt into my Eſtate? Ha! or have you been really a Steward, and cheated me out of a Fortune for your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Sir, what I am Maſter off, I got fairly under you, part, and part under my Lord Belville in Ireland, whom I ſerv'd twenty Years in the ſame Poſt I do you; when he died, he truſted me with a Secret, which yet I have divulged to no Man; and when I do, the World will ſay I am an honeſt Man. Love firſt join'd their Hearts, and my Ignorance their Hands; uſe me as you pleaſe, but pardon them.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I muſt become an Interceſſor in that too, Sir Jeffrey; Love is the great Cementer of the Marriage State; it reconciles all Differences—it bends the Stubborn—and it tames the Bold, it wins the Haughty, ſoftens the Savage, and reclaims the Libertine; then will you caſt off your Son for a Vertue, you ought rather to prize him for?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: That Love can never be a Vertue, Mr. Lovely, that teaches a Child to trick his Parents.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Stratagems ever were allow'd of in Love and War; Sir, you muſt forgive him.

div.stage: Enter Captain Conſtant, Belinda and Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I muſt ſecond Mr. Lovely, Sir, the Captain has married a virtuous Woman, and I believe you'll confeſs a handſome one too.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Nay, I have nothing to ſay againſt her Virtue, nor her Beauty neither; ſhe's a pretty Woman, that's the truth on't; if ſhe had married any Body's Son but mine, I ſhou'd have wiſh'd her Joy with all my heart——Oh thou graceleſs Wretch, get out of my ſight.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Kneeling. I confeſs, Sir, I am unworthy of your Mercy, but throw my ſelf wholly upon your good Nature and fatherly Affection, with this Reſolution, never to attempt ought againſt your Pleaſure more.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: No, Sir, nothing you can do for the future, ſhall either pleaſe, or diſpleaſe me; mark that.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Give us but your Bleſſing, Sir, and we ſhall never quarrel with Fortune for her Favours, Love ſhall ſupply that defect; my chief Concern ſhall be to ſhew my Duty, and by my Care to pleaſe you, prove the entire Affection I have for your Son; and that way make up the inequality of my Birth and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: You ſhall never make up any thing with me, I promiſe you, Madam, whilſt he is your Father—Death, marry my Slave?

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: The name of Slave belongs not to us free-born People, Sir Jeffrey; but were I your Slave, ſhe is not; for ſince the truth muſt out, ſhe is no Child of mine, but Daughter to my Lord Belville; which I have brought up ever ſince ſhe was three days old; her Mother dying in her Labour, and her Marriage being private, becauſe ſhe was much below my Lord's Quality; and He at that time under the tuition of a Father; He never made it publick, but put her into my hands to breed up as my own; when he came to his Eſtate, he purchas'd a thouſand Pounds a Year, and ſettled it on her; which I have manag'd ever ſince, and now will deliver it up to Captain Conſtant. This I had told in the Infancy of their Loves; but that I ſaw your Son was not well with you, and did not then think him a Match good enough for her; but ſince he has over reach'd me, I hope you'll prove a Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Is it poſſible! Od, Madam, I wiſh you Joy with all my Soul, Faith I do; and if this is matter of Fact, you ſhall find me a Father, Jack: You ſhall go to Flanders no more.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Dear Conſtant, I congratulate thy good For • une—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I your's, Madam, ſince I 〈…〉 Couſin.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Still let me hold that Name; for ſince I never know my Father, I ſhall acknowledge this good Man as ſuch.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir Jeffrey, I was poſitive you wou'd not report.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: You that are ſo poſitive in theſe matters; why don't you and Mr. Lovely ſtrike up a Bargain? he has follow'd you a conſiderable time.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
That Queſtion is A-propos, Sir Je •••••
; What can you ſay, Madam? muſt I dangle after your two or three Ye • rs 〈…〉 , I wiſh I hold out.

sp.speaker: Lov.

sp.speaker: Sir Da • .
sp.p: 〈…〉 they are.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And with my own Conſent, Paſſure you—You may barricade your Windows now, Sir David, I ſhall run mad no more; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I ſhall trouble your Houſe no more, Sir, I am diſpoſſeſs'd, Sir David, you need not run from me now; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: And he will know his Inn for the future, Sir, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: And am perfectly recover'd of my Wound, Sir; and ſhall have no occaſion to borrow your Coach again; without you'll do me the favour to let it carry my Wife to London.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Carry her to Hell—Here's a ſhuffling cutting Raſcal in all his Tropes and Figures: Zounds, how I am trick'd; But you have robb'd me, Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Of nothing but my Writings, Sir, mark that.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: The Law ſhall tell you that; and ſo, may the itch of Variety ſeize you, and the Curſe of Cuckoldom fall on him, Arreſts and Poverty on you all. Ex.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; now Lovely, for the Parſon.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Hold! I forbid the Banes; you ſhan't have her, mun, for all you are ſo Cock ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What Banes do you forbid, Friend?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Why Mr. Truſty's Daughter's Banes.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Alas! 'Squire, you come too late; She that was Mr. Truſty's Daughter, is married; and I am juſt going to't.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: That was! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why I mean that Mrs. Belinda, that has ſnapt your Heart, 'Squire, proves to be a Lord's Daughter, and not Mr. Truſty's, as you believe; and now is Captain Conſtant's Wife, here.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: A Lord's Daughter! Nounds, I'm glad▪ I'm rid of her— Captain, I wiſh you much Joy with all my heart—Od, I'll engage ſhe ſhakes your Commiſſion for you; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Why, what Luck have I had, Slouch! Mercy on us; what a Ruin had I brought upon all our Country Gentlemen innocently? For ſhe wou'd have corrupted all their Wives; the Devil a one wou'd have made her own Butter, after being acquainted with her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh! you miſtake, 'Squire, I am an excellent Houſewife; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, ſome in our Country knows by woful Experience, what Houſewifes you Quality make; Nounds, 'twou'd undo the High Sheriff of the County to find you in clean Cards; then your
plaguy O • tlandiſh Liquors, your Coff • e and Tea, ſucks up the Cr ••• r 〈◊〉 whole D • ry, and your 〈…〉 Collips wou'd confound all the 〈◊〉 and 〈…〉 you game away, wou'd ruin a Lord of a Mannor, No, no, no Quality Breed for us Country Gentlemen 〈…〉 worſe than double Tax •
• ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha; Well then, 'Squire, I have done you a 〈◊〉 of Service; I hope all Animoſities are forgot.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: They are i • ſaith, Sir; and if you'll 〈◊〉 me low 〈…〉 heartily merry with you.

sp.speaker: Truſty.

You ſhall b •

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: Come, let's in then, 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Save you all—Maſter and Landlord that was, and Maſte • and Landlord that is, I'm glad to hear all i • eve • wi • h 〈◊〉 Soul—I hope you'll not forget your promiſe th •• to 〈◊〉 Tenānt Roger——which was to ſpeak to Maſter——no, no, no ſpeak to your ſelf now▪ Sir—My Farm is woundy dear.

sp.speaker: Truſty.
sp.p: You are wondre •• merry, Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: So is every body you know, Sir, when they are prepare • for the Parſon; are they not, Mrs. Belinda? I hope I ſhall h • v • your Conſent; for I have got D • lly in the mind at laſt.

sp.speaker: Bel.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: The beſt Proviſion I deſire, is to wait on my Lady ſtill, 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Man.

sp.speaker: Conſt.

sp.speaker: Sir 〈◊〉
sp.p: Well, 〈…〉 Song now, I'll 〈…〉 the Rent for the next 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Say you ſo? I thank you heartily, Maſter, I'll do my beſt, I can't ſing like your Londoners—But 'tis a new Ballad; and 'twas made at London, by a very honeſt Country Gentleman, laſt Seſſions of Parliament. Hum, hum. Sings.
Ads blead, you ſing, Sir; and the 'Squire by, that's more than any Man in Zumerſetſhire will venture to do: Maſter, Ods Wounds, hold your own, Maſter.

div.head: A SONG, by the Author, and ſung by Mr. Dogget.

lg.l: Wou'd you ch • ſe a Wife f • r a happy Life,
Leave the Court, and the C • untry take,
Where Dolly and She, young Molly and Prue,
Follow Roger and John, a • ilſt Harveſt goes on,
And merrily, merrily Rake.
Leave the London Dames, be it ſpoke to their Shames,
To lig in their Beds till Noon;
Then get up and firetch, then paint too and patch,
Some Widgeon to catch, then look on their Watch,
And wonder they riſe up ſo ſoon.
Then Coffee and Tea, both Green and Bohea,
Is ſerv'd to their Tables in Plate;
Where their Tattles do run, as ſwift as the Sun,
Of what they have wone, and who is undone,
By their gaming, and ſitting up late.
The Laſs give me here, tho' brown as my Beer,
That knows how to govern her Houſe;
That can milk her Cow, or Farrow her Sow;
Make Butter, or Cheeſe, or gather green Peaſe,
And values fine Cloaths not a Louſe.
This, this is the Girl, worth Rubies and Pearl;
This the Wife that will make a Man rich:
We Gentlemen need, no Quality Breed,
To ſquander away, what Taxes would pay,
In troth we care for none ſuch.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Now I am happy—
Belinda mine, and you my faults forgive;
'Tis from this moment I begin to live.
Love ſprung the Mine, and made the Breach in Duty,
No Cannon Ball can execute like Beauty.
But I'll no more in ſearch of Pleaſures rove,
Since ev'ry Bleſſing is cōmpriz'd in Love. Exeunt.
